play.title:
THE TRAGEDIE OF
ROMEO and IVLIET.

scene.stagedir: Enter Sampſon and Gregory, with Swords and Bucklers, of the Houſe of Capulet.

speech.speaker: Sampſon.
speech.line: Gregory: A my word wee’l not carry coales.

speech.speaker: Greg.
speech.line: No, for then we ſhould be Colliars.

speech.speaker: Samp.
speech.line: I mean, if we be in choller, wee’l draw.

speech.speaker: Greg.
speech.line: I, While you liue, draw your necke out
o’th Collar.

speech.speaker: Samp.
speech.line: I ſtrike quickly, being mou’d.

speech.speaker: Greg.
speech.line: But thou art not quickly mou’d to ſtrike.

speech.speaker: Samp.
speech.line: A dog of the houſe of Mountague, moues me.

speech.speaker: Greg.
speech.line: To moue, is to ſtir: and to be valiant, is to ſtand:
Therefore, if thou art mou’d, thou runſt away.

speech.speaker: Samp.
speech.line: A dogge of that houſe ſhall moue me to ſtand.
I will take the wall of any Man or Maid of Mountagues.

speech.speaker: Greg.
speech.line: That ſhewes thee a weake ſlaue, for the wea—
keſt goes to the wall.

speech.speaker: Samp.
speech.line: True, and therefore women being the weaker
Veſſels, are euer thruſt to the wall: therefore I will puſh
Mountagues men from the wall, and thruſt his Maides to the wall.

speech.speaker: Greg.
speech.line: The Quarrell is betweene our Maſters, and vs their men.

speech.speaker: Samp.
speech.line: ’Tis all one, I will ſhew my ſelfe a tyrant: when
I haue fought with the men, I will bee ciuill with the
Maids, and cut off their heads.

speech.speaker: Greg.
speech.line: The heads of the Maids?

speech.speaker: Sam.
speech.line: I, the heads of the Maids, or their Maiden-heads,
Take it in what ſence thou wilt.

speech.speaker: Greg.
speech.line: They muſt take it ſence, that feele it.

speech.speaker: Samp.
speech.line: Me they ſhall feele while I am able to ſtand:
And ’tis knowne I am a pretty peece of fleſh.

speech.speaker: Greg.
speech.line: ’Tis well thou art not Fiſh: If thou had’ſt, thou
had’ſt beene poore Iohn. Draw thy Toole, here comes of
the Houſe of the Mountagues.

speech.speaker: Sam.
speech.line: My naked weapon is out: quarrel, I wil back thee

speech.speaker: Gre.
speech.line: How? Turne thy backe, and run.

speech.speaker: Sam.
speech.line: Feare me not.

speech.speaker: Gre.
speech.line: No marry: I feare thee.

speech.speaker: Sam.
speech.line: Let vs take the Law of our ſides: let them begin.

speech.speaker: Gr.
speech.line: I wil frown as I paſſe by, & let thé take it as they liſt

speech.speaker: Sam.
speech.line: Nay, as they dare. I wil bite my Thumb at them,
which is a diſgrace to them, if they beare it.

speech.speaker: Abra.
speech.line: Do you bite your Thumbe at vs ſir?

speech.speaker: Samp.
speech.line: I do bite my Thumbe, ſir.

speech.speaker: Abra.
speech.line: Do you bite your Thumb at vs, ſir?

speech.speaker: Sam.
speech.line: Is the Law of our ſide, if I ſay I?

speech.speaker: Gre.
speech.line: No.

speech.speaker: Sam.
speech.line: No ſir, I do not bite my Thumbe at you ſir: but
I bite my Thumbe ſir.

speech.speaker: Greg.
speech.line: Do you quarrell ſir?

speech.speaker: Abra.
speech.line: Quarrell ſir? no ſir.

speech.speaker: Sam.
speech.line: If you do ſir, I am for you, I ſerue as good a man as you

speech.speaker: Abra.
speech.line: No better?

speech.speaker: Samp.
speech.line: Well ſir.

speech.speaker: Gr.
speech.line: Say better: here comes one of my maſters kinſmen.

speech.speaker: Samp.
speech.line: Yes, better.

speech.speaker: Abra.
speech.line: You Lye.

speech.speaker: Samp.
speech.line: Draw if you be men. Gregory, remember thy waſhing blow.

speech.speaker: Ben.
speech.line: Part Fooles, put vp your Swords, you know not
what you do.

speech.speaker: Tyb.
speech.line: What art thou drawne, among theſe heartleſſe
Hindes? Turne thee Benuolio, looke vpon thy death.

speech.speaker: Ben.
speech.line: I do but keepe the peace, put vp thy Sword,
Or manage it to part theſe men with me.

speech.speaker: Tyb.
speech.line: What draw, and talke of peace? I hate the word
As I hate hell, all Mountagues, and thee:
Haue at thee Coward.

scene.stagedir: Enter three or foure Citizens with Clubs.

speech.speaker: Offi.
speech.line: Clubs, Bils, and Partiſons, ſtrike, beat them down
Downe with the Capulets, downe with the Mountagues.

scene.stagedir: Enter old Capulet in his Gowne, and his wife.

speech.speaker: Cap.
speech.line: What noiſe is this? Giue me my long Sword ho.

speech.speaker: Wife.
speech.line: A crutch, a crutch: why call you for a Sword?

speech.speaker: Cap.
speech.line: My Sword I ſay: Old Mountague is come,
And flouriſhes his Blade in ſpight of me.

speech.speaker: Moun.
speech.line: Thou villaine Capulet. Hold me not, let me go

speech.speaker: 2.Wife.
speech.line: Thou ſhalt not ſtir a foote to ſeeke a Foe.

scene.stagedir: Enter Prince Eskales, with his Traine.

speech.speaker: Prince.
speech.line: Rebellious Subieƈts, Enemies to peace,
Prophaners of this Neighbor-ſtained Steele,
Will they not heare? What hoe, you Men, you Beaſts,
That quench the fire of your pernitious Rage,
With purple Fountaines iſſuing from your Veines:
On paine of Torture, from thoſe bloody hands
Throw your miſtemper’d Weapons to the ground,
And heare the Sentence of your mooued Prince.
Three ciuill Broyles, bred of an Ayery word,
By thee old Capulet and Mountague,
Haue thrice disturb’d the quiet of our ſtreets,
And made Verona's ancient Citizens
Caſt by their Graue beſeeming Ornaments,
To wield old Partizans, in hands as old,
Cankred with peace, to part your Cankred hate,
If euer you diſturbe our ſtreets againe,
Your liues ſhall pay the forfeit of the peace.
For this time all the reſt depart away:
You Capulet ſhall goe along with me,
And Mountague come you this afternoone,
To know our Fathers pleaſure in this caſe:
To old Free-towne, our common iudgement place:
Once more on paine of death, all men depart.

speech.speaker: Moun.
speech.line: Who ſet this auncient quarrell new abroach?
Speake Nephew, were you by, when it began:

speech.speaker: Ben.
speech.line: Heere were the ſeruants of your aduerſarie,
And yours cloſe fighting ere I did approach,
I drew to part them, in the inſtant came
The fiery Tibalt, with his ſword prepar’d,
Which as he breath’d defiance to my eares,
He ſwong about his head, and cut the windes,
Who nothing hurt withall, hiſt him in ſcorne.
While we were enterchanging thruſts and blowes,
Came more and more, and fought on part and part,
Till the Prince came, who parted either part.

speech.speaker: Wife.
speech.line: O where is Romeo, ſaw you him to day?
Right glad am I, he was not at this fray.

speech.speaker: Ben.
speech.line: Madam, an houre before the worſhipt Sun
Peer’d forth the golden window of the Eaſt,
A troubled mind draue me to walke abroad,
Where vnderneath the groue of Sycamour,
That Weſt-ward rooteth from this City ſide:
So earely walking did I ſee your Sonne:
Towards him I made, but he was ware of me,
And ſtole into the couert of the wood,
I meaſuring his affeƈtions by my owne,
Which then moſt ſought, wher moſt might not be found:
Being one too many by my weary ſelfe,
Purſued my Honour, not purſuing his
And gladly ſhunn’d, who gladly fled from me.

speech.speaker: Mount.
speech.line: Many a morning hath he there beene ſeene,
With teares augmenting the freſh mornings deaw,
Adding to cloudes, more cloudes with his deepe ſighes,
But all ſo ſoone as the all-cheering Sunne,
Should in the fartheſt Eaſt begin to draw
The ſhadie Curtaines from Auroras bed,
Away from light ſteales home my heauy Sonne,
And priuate in his Chamber pennes himſelfe,
Shuts vp his windowes, lockes faire day-light out,
And makes himſelfe an artificiall night:
Blacke and portendous muſt this humour proue,
Vnleſſe good counſell may the cauſe remoue.

speech.speaker: Ben.
speech.line: My Noble Vncle doe you know the cauſe?

speech.speaker: Moun.
speech.line: I neither know it, nor can learne of him.

speech.speaker: Ben.
speech.line: Haue you importun’d him by any meanes?

speech.speaker: Moun.
speech.line: Both by my ſelfe and many other Friends,
But he his owne affeƈtions counſeller,
Is to himselfe (I will not ſay how true)
But to himſelfe ſo ſecret and ſo cloſe,
So farre from ſounding and diſcouery,
As is the bud bit with an enuious worme,
Ere he can ſpread his ſweete leaues to the ayre,
Or dedicate his beauty to the ſame.
Could we but learne from whence his ſorrowes grow,
We would as willingly giue cure, as know.

speech.speaker: Ben.
speech.line: See where he comes, ſo pleaſe you ſtep aſide,
Ile know his greeuance, or be much denide.

speech.speaker: Moun.
speech.line: I would thou wert ſo happy by thy ſtay,
To heare true ſhrift. Come Madam let's away.

speech.speaker: Ben.
speech.line: Good morrow Couſin.

speech.speaker: Rom.
speech.line: Is the day ſo young?

speech.speaker: Ben.
speech.line: But new ſtrooke nine.

speech.speaker: Rom.
speech.line: Aye me, ſad houres ſeeme long:
Was that my Father that went hence ſo fast?

speech.speaker: Ben.
speech.line: It was: what ſadnes lengthens Romeo's houres?

speech.speaker: Ro.
speech.line: Not hauing that, which hauing, makes them ſhort

speech.speaker: Ben.
speech.line: In loue.

speech.speaker: Romeo.
speech.line: Out.

speech.speaker: Ben.
speech.line: Of loue.

speech.speaker: Rom.
speech.line: Out of her fauour where I am in loue.

speech.speaker: Ben.
speech.line: Alas that loue ſo gentle in his view,
Should be ſo tyrannous and rough in proofe.

speech.speaker: Rom.
speech.line: Alas that loue, whoſe view is muffled ſtill,
Should without eyes, ſee path-wayes to his will:
Where ſhall we dine? O me: what fray was heere?
Yet tell me not, for I haue heard it all:
Heere's much to do with hate, but more with loue:
Why then, O brawling loue, O louing hate,
O any thing, of nothing firſt created:
O heauie lightneſſe, ſerious vanity,
Miſhapen Chaos of welſeeing formes,
Feather of lead, bright ſmoake, cold fire, ſicke health,
Still waking ſleepe, that is not what it is:
This loue feele I, that feele no loue in this.
Doeſt thou not laugh?

speech.speaker: Ben.
speech.line: No Coze, I rather weepe.

speech.speaker: Rom.
speech.line: Good heart, at what?

speech.speaker: Ben.
speech.line: At thy good hearts oppreſsion.

speech.speaker: Rom.
speech.line: Why ſuch is loues tranſgreſsion.
Griefes of mine owne lie heauie in my breaſt,
Which thou wilt propagate to haue it preaſt
With more of thine, this loue that thou haſt ſhowne,
Doth adde more griefe, to too much of mine owne.
Loue, is a ſmoake made with the fume of ſighes,
Being purg’d, a fire ſparkling in Louers eyes,
Being vext, a Sea nouriſht with louing teares,
What is it elſe? a madneſſe, moſt diſcreet,
A choking gall, and a preſeruing ſweet:
Farewell my Coze.

speech.speaker: Ben.
speech.line: Soft I will goe along.
And if you leaue me ſo, you do me wrong.

speech.speaker: Rom.
speech.line: Tut I haue loſt my ſelfe, I am not here,
This is not Romeo, hee’s ſome other where.

speech.speaker: Ben.
speech.line: Tell me in ſadneſſe, who is that you loue?

speech.speaker: Rom.
speech.line: What ſhall I grone and tell thee?

speech.speaker: Ben.
speech.line: Grone, why no: but ſadly tell me who.

speech.speaker: Rom.
speech.line: A ſicke man in ſadneſſe makes his will:
A word ill vrg’d to one that is ſo ill:
In ſadneſſe Cozin, I do loue a woman.

speech.speaker: Ben.
speech.line: I aym’d ſo neare, when I ſuppos’d you lou’d.

speech.speaker: Rom.
speech.line: A right good marke man, and ſhee’s faire I loue

speech.speaker: Ben.
speech.line: A right faire marke, faire Coze, is ſooneſt hit.

speech.speaker: Rom.
speech.line: Well in that hit you miſſe, ſheel not be hit
With Cupids arrow, ſhe hath Dians wit:
And in ſtrong proofe of chaſtity well arm’d:
From loues weake childiſh Bow, ſhe liues vncharm’d.
Shee will not ſtay the ſiege of louing tearmes,
Nor bid th’ incounter of aſſailing eyes.
Nor open her lap to Sainƈt-ſeducing Gold:
O ſhe is rich in beautie, onely poore,
That when ſhe dies, with beautie dies her ſtore.

speech.speaker: Ben.
speech.line: Then ſhe hath ſworne, that ſhe will ſtill liue chaſt?

speech.speaker: Rom.
speech.line: She hath, and in that ſparing make huge waſt?
For beauty ſteru’d with her ſeuerity,
Cuts beauty off from all poſteritie.
She is too faire, too wiſe: wiſely too faire,
To merit bliſſe by making me diſpaire:
She hath forſworne to loue, and in that vow
Do I liue dead, that liue to tell it now.

speech.speaker: Ben.
speech.line: Be rul’d by me, forget to thinke of her.

speech.speaker: Rom.
speech.line: O teach me how I ſhould forget to thinke.

speech.speaker: Ben.
speech.line: By giuing liberty vnto thine eyes,
Examine other beauties,

speech.speaker: Ro.
speech.line: ‘Tis the way to cal hers (exquiſit) in queſtion more,
Theſe happy maskes that kiſſe faire Ladies browes,
Being blacke, puts vs in mind they hide the faire:
He that is ſtrooken blind, cannot forget
The precious treaſure of his eye-ſight loſt:
Shew me a Miſtreſſe that is paſſing faire,
What doth her beauty ſerue but as a note,
Where I may read who paſt that paſſing faire.
Farewell thou can’ſt not teach me to forget,

speech.speaker: Ben
speech.line: Ile pay that doƈtrine, or elſe die in debt.

scene.stagedir: Enter Capulet, Countie Paris, and the Clowne.

speech.speaker: Capu.
speech.line: Mountague is bound as well as I,
In penalty alike, and ‘tis not hard I thinke,
For men ſo old as wee, to keepe the peace.

speech.speaker: Par.
speech.line: Of Honourable reckoning are you both,
And pittie ‘tis you liu’d at ods ſo long:
But now my Lord, what ſay you to my ſute?

speech.speaker: Capu.
speech.line: But ſaying ore what I haue ſaid before,
My Child is yet a ſtranger in the world,
Shee hath not ſeene the change of fourteene yeares,
Let two more Summers wither in their pride,
Ere we may thinke her ripe to be a Bride.

speech.speaker: Pari.
speech.line: Younger then ſhe, are happy mothers made.

speech.speaker: Capu.
speech.line: And too ſoone mar’d are those ſo early made:
Earth hath ſwallowed all my hopes but ſhe,
Shee's the hopefull Lady of my earth:
But wooe her gentle Paris, get her heart,
My will to her conſent, is but a part,
And ſhee agree, within her ſcope of choiſe,
Lyes my conſent, and faire according voice:
This night I hold an old accuſtom’d Feaſt,
Whereto I haue inuited many a Gueſt,
Such as I loue, and you among the ſtore,
One more, moſt welcome makes my number more:
At my poore houſe, looke to behold this night,
Earth-treading ſtarres, that make darke heauen light,
Such comfort as do luſty young men feele,
When well apparrel’d Aprill on the heele
Of limping Winter treads, euen ſuch delight
Among freſh Fennell buds ſhall you this night
Inherit at my houſe: heare all, all ſee:
And like her moſt, whoſe merit moſt ſhall be:
Which one more veiw, of many, mine being one,
May ſtand in number, though in reckning none.
Come, goe with me: goe ſirrah trudge about,
Through faire Verona, find thoſe perſons out,
Whoſe names are written there, and to them ſay,
My houſe and welcome, on their pleaſure ſtay.

speech.speaker: Ser.
speech.line: Find them out whoſe names are written. Heere it
is written, that the Shoo-maker ſhould meddle with his
Yard, and the Tayler with his Laſt, the Fiſher with his
Penſill, and the Painter with his Nets. But I am ſent to
find thoſe perſons whoſe names are writ, & can neuer find
what names the writing perſon hath here writ (I muſt to
the learned) in good time.

speech.speaker: Ben.
speech.line: Tut man, one fire burnes out anothers burning,
One paine is leſned by anothers anguiſh:
Turne giddie, and be holpe by backward turning:
One deſparate greefe, cures with anothers languiſh:
Take thou ſome new infeƈtion to the eye,
And the rank poyſon of the old wil die.

speech.speaker: Rom.
speech.line: Your Plantan leafe is excellent for that.

speech.speaker: Ben.
speech.line: For what I pray thee?

speech.speaker: Rom.
speech.line: For your broken ſhin.

speech.speaker: Ben.
speech.line: Why Romeo art thou mad?

speech.speaker: Rom.
speech.line: Not mad, but bound more then a mad man is:
Shut vp in priſon, kept without my foode,
Whipt and tormented: and Godden good fellow,

speech.speaker: Ser.
speech.line: Godgigoden, I pray ſir can you read?

speech.speaker: Rom.
speech.line: I mine owne fortune in my miſerie.

speech.speaker: Ser.
speech.line: Perhaps you haue learn’d it without booke:
But I pray can you read any thing you ſee?

speech.speaker: Rom.
speech.line: I, if I know the Letters and the Language.

speech.speaker: Ser.
speech.line: Ye ſay honeſtly, reſt you merry.

speech.speaker: Rom.
speech.line: Stay fellow, I can read.

line.recite: Seigneur Martino, and his wife and daughter: County An-
ſelme and his beautious ſiſters: the Lady widdow of Vtru-
uio, Seigneur Placentio, and his louely Neeces: Mercutio and
his brother Valentine: mine vncle Capulet his wife and daugh-
ters: my faire Neece Roſaline, Liuia, Seigneur Valentio, & his
Coſen Tybalt: Lucio and the liuely Helena.

speech.line: A faire aſſembly, whither ſhould they come?

speech.speaker: Ser.
speech.line: Vp.

speech.speaker: Rom.
speech.line: Whither? to ſupper?

speech.speaker: Ser.
speech.line: To our houſe.

speech.speaker: Rom.
speech.line: Whoſe houſe?

speech.speaker: Ser.
speech.line: My Maiſters.

speech.speaker: Rom.
speech.line: Indeed I ſhould haue askt you that before.

speech.speaker: Ser.
speech.line: Now Ile tell you without asking. My maiſter is
the great rich Capulet, and if you be not of the houſe of
Mountagues I pray come and cruſh a cup of wine. Reſt
you merry.

speech.speaker: Ben.
speech.line: At this ſame auncient Feaſt of Capulets
Sups the faire Roſaline, whom thou ſo loues:
With all the admired Beauties of Verona,
Go thither and with vnattainted eye,
Compare her face with ſome that I ſhall ſhow,
And I will make thee thinke thy Swan a Crow.

speech.speaker: Rom.
speech.line: When the deuout religion of mine eye
Maintaines ſuch falſhood, then turne teares to fire:
And theſe who often drown’d could neuer die,
Tranſparent Heretiques be burnt for liers.
One fairer then my loue: the all-ſeeing Sun
Nere ſaw her match, ſince firſt the world begun.

speech.speaker: Ben.
speech.line: Tut, you ſaw her faire, none elſe being by,
Herſelfe poyſ’d with herſelfe in either eye:
But in that Chriſtall ſcales, let there be waid,
Your Ladies loue againſt ſome other Maid
That I will ſhow you, ſhining at this Feaſt,
And ſhe ſhew ſcant ſhell, well, that now ſhewes beſt.

speech.speaker: Rom.
speech.line: Ile goe along, no ſuch ſight to be ſhowne,
But to reioyce in ſplendor of mine owne.

speech.speaker: Wife.
speech.line: Nurſe wher’s my daughter? call her forth to me.

speech.speaker: Nurſe.
speech.line: Now by my Maidenhead, at twelue yeare old
I bad her come, what Lamb: what Ladi-bird, God forbid,
Where's this Girle? what Iuliet?

speech.speaker: Iuliet.
speech.line: How now, who calls?

speech.speaker: Nur.
speech.line: Your Mother.

speech.speaker: Iuliet.
speech.line: Madam I am heere, what is your will?

speech.speaker: Wife.
speech.line: This is the matter: Nurſe giue leaue awhile, we
muſt talke in ſecret. Nurſe come backe againe, I haue re—
membred me, thou’ſe heare our counſell. Thou knoweſt
my daughter’s of a prety age.

speech.speaker: Nurſe.
speech.line: Faith I can tell her age vnto an houre.

speech.speaker: Wife.
speech.line: Shee’s not fourteene.

speech.speaker: Nurſe.
speech.line: Ile lay fourteene of my teeth,
And yet to my teene be it ſpoken,
I haue but foure, ſhee’s not fourteene.
How long is it now to Lammas tide?

speech.speaker: Wife.
speech.line: A fortnight and odde dayes.

speech.speaker: Nurſe.
speech.line: Euen or odde, of all daies in the yeare come
Lammas Eue at night ſhall ſhe be fourteene. Susan & ſhe,
God reſt all Chriſtian ſoules, were of an age. Well Susan
is with God, ſhe was too good for me. But as I ſaid, on La-
mas Eue at night ſhall ſhe be fourteene, that ſhall ſhe ma—
rie, I remember it well. ‘Tis ſince the Earth-quake now
eleuen yeares, and ſhe was wean’d I neuer ſhall forget it,
of all the daies of the yeare, vpon that day: for I had then
laid Worme-wood to my Dug ſitting in the Sunne vnder
the Douehouſe wall, my Lord and you were then at
Mantua, nay I doe beare a braine. But as I ſaid, when it
did taſt the Worme-wood on the nipple of my Dugge,
and felt it bitter, pretty foole, to ſee it teachie, and fall out
with the Dugge, Shake quoth the Doue-houſe, ‘twas no
neede I trow to bid mee trudge: and ſince that time it is
a eleuen yeares, for then ſhe could ſtand alone, nay bi’ th’
roode ſhe could haue runne, & wadled all about: for euen
the day before ſhe broke her brow, & then my Husband
God be with his ſoule, a was a merrie man, tooke vp the
Child, yea quoth hee, doeſt thou fall vpon thy face? thou
wilt fall backeward when thou haſt more wit, wilt thou
not Iule? And by my holy-dam, the pretty wretch lefte
crying, & ſaid I: to ſee now how a Iest ſhall come about.
I warrant, & I ſhall liue a thouſand yeares, I neuer ſhould
forget it: wilt thou not Iule quoth he? and pretty foole it
ſtinted, and ſaid I.

speech.speaker: Old La.
speech.line: Inough of this, I pray thee hold thy peace.

speech.speaker: Nurſe.
speech.line: Yes Madam, yet I cannot chuſe but laugh, to
thinke it ſhould leaue crying, & ſay I: and yet I warrant
it had vpon it brow, a bumpe as big as a young Cockrels
ſtone? A perilous knock, and it cryed bitterly. Yea quoth
my husband, fall’ſt vpon thy face, thou wilt fall back—
ward when thou commeſt to age: wilt thou not Iule? It
ſtinted: and ſaid I.

speech.speaker: Iule.
speech.line: And ſtint thou too, I pray thee Nurſe, ſay I.

speech.speaker: Nur.
speech.line: Peace I haue done: God marke thee too his grace
thou waſt the prettieſt Babe that ere I nurſt, and I might
liue to ſee thee married once, I haue my wiſh.

speech.speaker: Old La.
speech.line: Marry that marry is the very theame
I came to talke of, tell me daughter Iuliet,
How ſtands your diſpoſition to be Married?

speech.speaker: Iuli.
speech.line: It is an houre that I dreame not of.

speech.speaker: Nur.
speech.line: An houre, were not I thine onely Nurſe, I would
ſay thou had’ſt ſuckt wiſedome from thy teat.

speech.speaker: Old La.
speech.line: Well thinke of marriage now, yonger then you
Heere in Verona, Ladies of eſteeme,
Are made already Mothers. By my count
I was your Mother, much vpon theſe yeares
That you are now a Maide, thus then in briefe:
The valiant Paris ſeekes you for his loue.

speech.speaker: Nurſe.
speech.line: A man young Lady, Lady, ſuch a man as all
the world. Why hee’s a man of waxe.

speech.speaker: Old La.
speech.line: Veronas Summer hath not ſuch a flower.

speech.speaker: Nurſe.
speech.line: Nay hee’s a flower, infaith a very flower.

speech.speaker: Old La.
speech.line: What ſay you, can you loue the Gentleman?
This night you ſhall behold him at our Feaſt,
Read ore the volume of young Paris face,
And find delight, writ there with Beauties pen:
Examine euery ſeuerall liniament,
And ſee how one another lends content:
And what obſcur’d in this faire volume lies,
Find written in the Margent of his eyes.
This precious Booke of Loue, this vnbound Louer,
To Beautifie him, onely lacks a Couer.
The fiſh liues in the Sea, and ‘tis much pride
For faire without, the faire within to hide:
That Booke in manies eyes doth ſhare the glorie,
That in Gold claſpes, Lockes in the Golden ſtorie:
So ſhall you ſhare all that he doth poſſeſſe,
By hauing him, making your ſelfe no leſſe.

speech.speaker: Nurſe.
speech.line: No leſſe, nay bigger: women grow by men.

speech.speaker: Old La.
speech.line: Speake briefly, can you like of Paris loue?

speech.speaker: Iuli.
speech.line: Ile looke to like, if looking liking moue.
But no more deepe will I endart mine eye,
Then your conſent giues ſtrength to make flye.

speech.speaker: Ser.
speech.line: Madam, the gueſts are come, ſupper ſeru’d vp, you
cal’d, my young Lady askt for, the Nurſe cur’ſt in the Pan—
tery, and euery thing in extremitie: I muſt hence to wait, I
beſeech you follow ſtraight.

speech.speaker: Mo.
speech.line: We follow thee, Iuliet, the Countie ſtaies.

speech.speaker: Nurſe.
speech.line: Goe Gyrle, ſeeke happie nights to happy daies.

scene.stagedir: Enter Romeo, Mercutio, Benuolio, with fiue or ſixe other Maskers, Torch-bearers.

speech.speaker: Rom.
speech.line: What ſhall this ſpech be ſpoke for our excuſe?
Or ſhall we on without Apologie?

speech.speaker: Ben.
speech.line: The date is out of ſuch prolixitie,
Weele haue no Cupid, hood winkt with a skarfe,
Bearing a Tartars painted Bow of lath,
Skaring the Ladies like a Crow-keeper.
But let them meaſure vs by what they will,
Weele meaſure them with a Meaſure, and be gone.

speech.speaker: Rom.
speech.line: Giue me a Torch, I am not for this ambling.
Being but heauy I will beare the light.

speech.speaker: Mer.
speech.line: Nay gentle Romeo, we muſt haue you dance.

speech.speaker: Rom.
speech.line: Not I beleeue me, you haue dancing ſhooes
With nimble ſoles, I haue a ſoale of Lead
So ſtakes me to the ground, I cannot moue.

speech.speaker: Mer.
speech.line: You are a Louer, borrow Cupids wings,
And ſoare with them aboue a common bound.

speech.speaker: Rom.
speech.line: I am too ſore enpearced with his ſhaft,
To ſoare with his light feathers, and to bound:
I cannot bound a pitch aboue dull woe,
Vnder loues heauy burthen doe I ſinke.

speech.speaker: Hora.
speech.line: And to ſinke in it ſhould you burthen loue,
Too great oppreſſion for a tender thing.

speech.speaker: Rom.
speech.line: Is loue a tender thing? it is too rough,
Too rude, too boyſterous, and it pricks like thorne.

speech.speaker: Mer.
speech.line: If loue be rough with you, be rough with loue,
Pricke loue for pricking, and you beat loue downe,
Giue me a Caſe to put my viſage in,
A Viſor for a Viſor, what care I
What curious eye doth quote deformities:
Here are the Beetle-browes ſhall bluſh for me.

speech.speaker: Ben.
speech.line: Come knocke and enter, and no ſooner in,
But euery man betake him to his legs.

speech.speaker: Rom.
speech.line: A Torch for me, let wantons light of heart
Tickle the ſenceleſſe ruſhes with their heeles:
For I am prouerb’d with a Grandſier Phraſe,
Ile be a Candle-holder and looke on,
The game was nere ſo faire, and I am done.

speech.speaker: Mer.
speech.line: Tut, duns the Mouſe, the Conſtables owne word,
If thou art dun, weele draw thee from the mire.
Or ſaue your reuerence loue, wherein thou ſtickeſt
Vp to the eares, come we burne day-light ho.

speech.speaker: Rom.
speech.line: Nay that’s not ſo.

speech.speaker: Mer.
speech.line: I meane ſir I delay,
We waſt our lights in vaine, lights, lights, by day;
Take our good meaning, for our Iudgement ſits
Fiue times in that, ere once in our fiue wits.

speech.speaker: Rom.
speech.line: And we meane well in going to this Maske,
But ‘tis no wit to go.

speech.speaker: Mer.
speech.line: Why may one aske?

speech.speaker: Rom.
speech.line: I dreampt a dreame to night.

speech.speaker: Mer.
speech.line: And ſo did I.

speech.speaker: Rom.
speech.line: Well what was yours?

speech.speaker: Mer.
speech.line: That dreamers often lye.

speech.speaker: Ro.
speech.line: In bed a ſleepe while they do dreame things true.

speech.speaker: Mer.
speech.line: O then I ſee Queene Mab hath beene with you:
She is the Fairies Midwife, & ſhe comes in ſhape no big—
ger then Agat-ſtone, on the fore-finger of an Alderman,
drawne with a teeme of little Atomies, ouer mens noſes as
they lie aſleepe: her Waggon Spokes made of long Spin—
ners legs: the Couer of the wings of Graſhoppers, her
Traces of the ſmalleſt Spiders web, her coullers of the
Moonſhines watry Beames, her Whip of Crickets bone,
the Laſh of Philome, her Waggoner, a ſmall gray-coated
Gnat, not halfe ſo bigge as a round little Worme, prickt
from the Lazie-finger of a man. Her Chariot is an emptie
Haſelnut, made by the Ioyner Squirrel or old Grub, time
out a mind, the Faries Coach-makers: & in this ſtate ſhe
gallops night by night, through Louers braines: and then
they dreame of Loue. On Courtiers knees, that dreame on
Curſies ſtrait: ore Lawyers fingers, who ſtraits dreamt on
Fees, ore Ladies lips, who ſtrait on kiſſes dreame, which
oft the angry Mab with bliſters plagues, becauſe their
breath with Sweet meats tainted are. Sometime ſhe gal—
lops ore a Courtiers noſe, & then dreames he of ſmelling
out a ſute: & ſomtime comes ſhe with Tith pigs tale, tick—
ling a Parſons noſe as a lies aſleepe, then he dreames of
another Benefice. Sometime ſhe driueth ore a Souldiers
necke, & then dreames he of cutting Forraine throats, of
Breaches, Ambuſcados, Spaniſh Blades: Of Healths fiue
Fadome deepe, and then anon drums in his eares, at which
he ſtartes and wakes; and being thus frighted, ſweares a
prayer or two & ſleepes againe: this is that very Mab that
plats the manes of Horſes in the night: & bakes the Elk—
locks in foule ſluttiſh haires, which once vntangled, much
misfortune bodes.
This is the hag, when Maides lie on their backs,
That preſſes them, and learnes them firſt to beare,
Making them women of good carriage:
This is ſhe.

speech.speaker: Rom.
speech.line: Peace, peace, Mercutio peace,
Thou talk’ſt of nothing.

speech.speaker: Mer.
speech.line: True, I talke of dreames:
Which are the children of an idle braine,
Begot of nothing, but vaine phantaſie,
Which is as thin of ſubſtance as the ayre,
And more inconſtant then the wind, who wooes
Euen now the frozen boſome of the North:
And being anger’d, puffes away from thence,
Turning his ſide to the dew dropping South.

speech.speaker: Ben.
speech.line: This wind you talke of blowes vs from our ſelues,
Supper is done, and we ſhall come too late.

speech.speaker: Rom.
speech.line: I feare too early, for my mind miſgiues,
Some conſequence yet hanging in the ſtarres,
Shall bitterly begin his fearefull date
With this nights reuels, and expire the tearme
Of a deſpiſed life cloſ’d in my breſt:
By ſome vile forfeit of vntimely death.
But he that hath the ſtirrage of my courſe,
Direƈt my ſute: on luſtie Gentlemen.

speech.speaker: Ben.
speech.line: Strike Drum.

scene.stagedir: They march about the Stage, and Seruingmen come forth with their napkins.

speech.speaker: Ser.
speech.line: Where's Potpan, that he helpes not to take away?
He ſhift a Trencher? he ſcrape a Trencher?
When good manners, ſhall lie in one or two mens
hands, and they vnwaſht too, ‘tis a foule thing.

speech.speaker: Ser.
speech.line: Away with the Ioynſtooles, remoue the Court—
cubbord, looke to the Plate: good thou, ſaue mee a piece
of Marchpane, and as thou loueſt me, let the Porter let in
Suſan Grindſtone, and Nell, Anthonie and Potpan.
I Boy readie.

speech.speaker: Ser.
speech.line: You are lookt for, and cal’d for, askt for, & ſought
for, in the great Chamber.
We cannot be here and there too, chearly Boyes,
Be brisk awhile, and the longer liuer take all.

scene.stagedir: Enter all the Gueſts and Gentlewomen to the Maskers.

speech.speaker: 1. Capu.
speech.line: Welcome Gentlemen,
Ladies that haue their toes
Vnplagu’d with Cornes, will walke about with you:
Ah my Miſtreſſes, which of you all
Will now deny to dance? She that makes dainty,
She Ile ſweare hath Cornes: am I come neare ye now?
Welcome Gentlemen, I haue ſeene the day
That I haue worne a Viſor, and could tell
A whiſpering tale in a faire Ladies eare:
Such as would pleaſe: ‘tis gone, ‘tis gone, ‘tis gone,
You are welcome Gentlemen, come Muſitians play:
A Hall, Hall, giue roome, and foote it Girles,
More light you knaues, and turne the Tables vp:
And quench the fire, the Roome is growne too hot.
Ah ſirrah, this vnlookt for ſport comes well:
Nay ſit, nay ſit, good Cozin Capulet,
For you and I are paſt our dauncing daies:
How long ‘iſt now ſince laſt your ſelfe and I
Were in a Maske?

speech.speaker: 2. Capu.
speech.line: Berlady thirty yeares.

speech.speaker: 1. Capu.
speech.line: What man: ‘tis not ſo much, ‘tis not ſo much,
‘Tis ſince the Nuptiall of Lucentio,
Come Pentycoſt as quickely as it will,
Some fiue and twenty yeares, and then we Maskt.

speech.speaker: 2. Cap.
speech.line: ‘Tis more, ‘tis more, his Sonne is elder ſir:
His Sonne is thirty.

speech.speaker: 3. Cap.
speech.line: Will you tell me that?
His Sonne was but a Ward two yeares agoe.

speech.speaker: Rom.
speech.line: What Ladie is that which doth inrich the hand
Of yonder Knight?

speech.speaker: Ser.
speech.line: I know not ſir.

speech.speaker: Rom.
speech.line: O ſhe doth teach the Torches to burne bright:
It ſeemes ſhe hangs vpon the cheeke of night,
As a rich Iewel in an Æthiops eare:
Beauty too rich for vſe, for earth too deare:
So ſhewes a Snowy Doue trooping with Crowes,
As yonder Lady ore her fellowes ſhowes;
The meaſure done, Ile watch her place of ſtand,
And touching hers, make bleſſed my rude hand.
Did my heart loue till now, forſweare it ſight,
For I neuer ſaw true Beauty till this night.

speech.speaker: Tib.
speech.line: This by his voice, ſhould be a Mountague.
Fetch me my Rapier Boy, what dares the ſlaue
Come hither couer’d with an antique face,
To fleere and ſcorne at our Solemnitie?
Now by the ſtocke and Honour of my kin,
To ſtrike him dead I hold it not a ſin.

speech.speaker: Cap.
speech.line: Why how now kinſman,
Wherefore ſtorme you ſo?

speech.speaker: Tib.
speech.line: Vncle this is a Mountague, our foe:
A Villaine that is hither come in ſpight,
To ſcorne at our Solemnitie this night.

speech.speaker: Cap.
speech.line: Young Romeo is it?

speech.speaker: Tib.
speech.line: ‘Tis he, that Villaine Romeo.

speech.speaker: Cap.
speech.line: Content thee gentle Coz, let him alone,
A beares him like a portly Gentleman:
And to ſay truth, Verona brags of him,
To be a vertuous and well gouern’d youth:
I would not for the wealth of all the towne,
Here in my houſe do him diſparagement:
Therfore be patient, take no note of him,
It is my will, the which if thou reſpeƈt,
Shew a faire preſence, and put off theſe frownes,
An ill beſeeming ſemblance for a Feaſt.

speech.speaker: Tib.
speech.line: It fits when ſuch a Villaine is a gueſt,
Ile not endure him.

speech.speaker: Cap.
speech.line: He ſhall be endur’d.
What goodman boy, I ſay he ſhall, go too,
Am I the Maiſter here or you? go too,
Youle not endure him, God ſhall mend my ſoule,
Youle make a Mutinie among the Gueſts:
You will ſet cocke a hoope, youle be the man.

speech.speaker: Tib.
speech.line: Why Vncle, ‘tis a ſhame.

speech.speaker: Cap.
speech.line: Go too, go too,
You are a ſawcy Boy, ‘iſt ſo indeed?
This tricke may chance to ſcath you, I know what,
You muſt contrary me, marry ‘tis time.
Well ſaid my hearts, you are a Princox, goe,
Be quiet, or more light, more light for ſhame,
Ile make you quiet. What, chearely my hearts.

speech.speaker: Tib.
speech.line: Patience perforce, with wilfull choler meeting,
Makes my fleſh tremble in their different greeting:
I will withdraw, but this intruſion ſhall
Now ſeeming ſweet, conuert to bitter gall.

speech.speaker: Rom.
speech.line: If I prophane with my vnworthieſt hand,
This holy ſhrine, the gentle ſin is this,
My lips to bluſhing Pilgrims did ready ſtand,
To ſmooth that rough touch, with a tender kiſſe.

speech.speaker: Iul.
speech.line: Good Pilgrime,
You do wrong your hand too much.
Which mannerly deuotion ſhewes in this,
For Saints haue hands, that Pilgrims hands do tuch,
And palme to palme, is holy Palmers kiſſe.

speech.speaker: Rom.
speech.line: Haue not Saints lips, and holy Palmers too?

speech.speaker: Iul.
speech.line: I Pilgrim, lips that they muſt vſe in prayer.

speech.speaker: Rom.
speech.line: O then deare Saint, let lips do what hands do,
They pray (grant thou) leaſt faith turne to diſpaire.

speech.speaker: Iul.
speech.line: Saints do not moue,
Though grant for prayers ſake.

speech.speaker: Rom.
speech.line: Then moue not while my prayers effeƈt I take:
Thus from my lips, by thine my ſin is purg’d.

speech.speaker: Iul.
speech.line: Then haue my lips the ſin that they haue tooke.

speech.speaker: Rom.
speech.line: Sin from my lips? O treſpaſſe ſweetly vrg’d:
Giue me my ſin againe.

speech.speaker: Iul.
speech.line: You kiſſe by’ th’ booke.

speech.speaker: Nur.
speech.line: Madam your Mother craues a word with you.

speech.speaker: Rom.
speech.line: What is her Mother?

speech.speaker: Nurſ.
speech.line: Marrie Batcheler,
Her Mother is the Lady of the houſe,
And a good Lady, and a wiſe, and Vertuous,
I Nur’ſt her Daughter that you talkt withall:
I tell you, he that can lay hold of her,
Shall haue the chincks.

speech.speaker: Rom.
speech.line: Is ſhe a Capulet?
O deare account! My life is my foes debt.

speech.speaker: Ben.
speech.line: Away, be gone, the ſport is at the beſt.

speech.speaker: Rom.
speech.line: I ſo I feare, the more is my vnreſt.

speech.speaker: Cap.
speech.line: Nay Gentlemen prepare not to be gone,
We haue a trifling fooliſh Banquet towards:
Is it e’ne ſo? why then I thanke you all.
I thanke you honeſt Gentlemen, good night:
More Torches here: come on, then let’s to bed.
Ah ſirrah, by my faie it waxes late,
Ile to my reſt.

speech.speaker: Iuli.
speech.line: Come hither Nurſe,
What is yond Gentleman:

speech.speaker: Nur.
speech.line: The Sonne and Heire of old Tyberio.

speech.speaker: Iuli.
speech.line: What’s he that now is going out of doore?

speech.speaker: Nur.
speech.line: Marrie that I thinke be young Petruchio.

speech.speaker: Iul.
speech.line: What’s he that follows here that would not dance?

speech.speaker: Nur.
speech.line: I know not.

speech.speaker: Iul.
speech.line: Go aske his name: if he be married,
My graue is like to be my wedded bed.

speech.speaker: Nur.
speech.line: His name is Romeo, and a Mountague,
The onely Sonne of your great Enemie.

speech.speaker: Iul.
speech.line: My onely Loue ſprung from my onely hate,
Too early ſeene, vnknowne, and knowne too late,
Prodigious birth of Loue it is to me,
That I muſt loue a loathed Enemie.

speech.speaker: Nur.
speech.line: What’s this? whats this?

speech.speaker: Iul.
speech.line: A rime, I learne euen now
Of one I dan’ſt withall.

speech.speaker: Nur.
speech.line: Anon, anon:
Come let’s away, the ſtrangers all are gone.

speech.speaker: Chorus.
speech.line: Now old deſire doth in his death bed lie,
And yong affeƈtion gapes to be his Heire,
That faire, for which Loue gron’d for and would die,
With tender Iuliet matcht, is now not faire.
Now Romeo is beloued, and Loues againe,
A like bewitched by the charme of lookes:
But to his foe ſuppos’d he muſt complaine,
And ſhe ſteale Loues ſweet bait from fearefull hookes:
Being held a foe, he may not haue acceſſe
To breath ſuch vowes as Louers vſe to ſweare,
And ſhe as much in Loue, her meanes much leſſe,
To meete her new Beloued any where:
But paſſion lends them Power, time, meanes to meete,
Temp’ring extremities with extreame ſweete.

speech.speaker: Rom.
speech.line: Can I goe forward when my heart is here?
Turne backe dull earth, and find thy Center out.

speech.speaker: Ben.
speech.line: Romeo, my Cozen Romeo, Romeo.

speech.speaker: Merc.
speech.line: He is wiſe,
And on my life hath ſtolne him home to bed.

speech.speaker: Ben.
speech.line: He ran this way and leapt this Orchard wall.
Call good Mercutio:
Nay, Ile coniure too.

speech.speaker: Mer.
speech.line: Romeo, Humours, Madman, Paſſion, Louer,
Appeare thou in the likeneſſe of a ſigh,
Speake but one time, and I am ſatisfied:
Cry me but ay me, Prouant, but Loue and day,
Speake to my goſhip Venus one faire word,
One Nickname for her purblind Sonne and her,
Young Abraham Cupid he that ſhot ſo true,
When King Cophetua lou’d the begger Maid,
He heareth not, he ſtirreth not, he moueth not,
The Ape is dead, I muſt coniure him,
I coniure thee by Roſalines bright eyes,
By her High forehead, and her Scarlet lip,
By her Fine foote, Straight leg, and Quiuering thigh,
And the Demeanes, that there Adiacent lie,
That in thy likeneſſe thou appeare to vs.

speech.speaker: Ben.
speech.line: And if he heare thee thou wilt anger him.

speech.speaker: Mer.
speech.line: This cannot anger him, t’would anger him
To raiſe a ſpirit in his Miſtreſſe circle,
Of ſome ſtrange nature, letting it ſtand
Till ſhe had laid it, and coniured it downe,
That were ſome ſpight.
My inuocation is faire and honeſt, & in his Miſtris name,
I coniure onely but to raise vp him.

speech.speaker: Ben.
speech.line: Come, he hath hid himſelfe among theſe Trees
To be conſorted with the Humerous night:
Blind is his Loue, and beſt befits the darke.

speech.speaker: Mer.
speech.line: If Loue be blind, Loue cannot hit the marke,
Now will he ſit vnder a Medler tree,
And wiſh his Miſtreſſe were that kind of Fruite,
As Maides call Medlers when they laugh alone,
O Romeo that ſhe were, O that ſhe were
An open, or thou a Poprin Peare,
Romeo goodnight, Ile to my Truckle bed,
This Field bed is to cold for me to ſleepe,
Come ſhall we go?

speech.speaker: Ben.
speech.line: Go then, for ‘tis in vaine to ſeeke him here
That meanes not to be found.

speech.speaker: Rom.
speech.line: He ieaſts at Scarres that neuer felt a wound,
But ſoft, what light through yonder window breaks?
It is the Eaſt, and Iuliet is the Sunne,
Ariſe faire Sun and kill the enuious Moone,
Who is already ſicke and pale with griefe,
That thou her Maid art far more faire then ſhe:
Be not her Maid ſince ſhe is enuious,
Her Veſtal liuery is but ſicke and greene,
And none but fooles do weare it, caſt it off:
It is my Lady, O it is my Loue, O that ſhe knew ſhe were,
She ſpeakes, yet ſhe ſayes nothing, what of that?
Her eye diſcourſes, I will anſwere it:
I am too bold ‘tis not to me ſhe ſpeakes:
Two of the faireſt ſtarres in all the Heauen,
Hauing ſome buſineſſe do entreat her eyes,
To twinckle in their Spheres till they returne.
What if her eyes were there, they in her head,
The brightneſſe of her cheeke would ſhame thoſe ſtarres,
As day-light doth a Lampe, her eye in heauen,
Would through the ayrie Region ſtreame ſo bright,
That Birds would ſing, and thinke it were not night:
See how ſhe leanes her cheeke vpon her hand.
O that I were a Gloue vpon that hand,
That I might touch that cheeke.

speech.speaker: Iul.
speech.line: Ay me.

speech.speaker: Rom.
speech.line: She ſpeakes.
Oh ſpeake againe bright Angell, for thou art
As glorious to this night being ore my head,
As is a winged meſſenger of heauen
Vnto the white vpturned wondring eyes
Of mortalls that fall backe to gaze on him,
When he beſtrides the lazie puffing Cloudes,
And ſailes vpon the boſome of the ayre.

speech.speaker: Iul.
speech.line: O Romeo, Romeo, wherefore art thou Romeo?
Denie thy Father and refuſe thy name:
Or if thou wilt not, be but ſworne to my Loue,
And Ile no longer be a Capulet.

speech.speaker: Rom.
speech.line: Shall I heare more, or ſhall I ſpeake at this?

speech.speaker: Iu.
speech.line: ‘Tis but thy name that is my Enemy:
Thou art thy ſelfe, though not a Mountague,
What's Mountague? it is nor hand nor foote,
Nor arme, nor face, O be ſome other name
Belonging to a man.
What? in a names that which we call a Roſe,
By any other word would ſmell as ſweete,
So Romeo would, were he not Romeo cal’d,
Retaine that deare perfeƈtion which he owes,
Without that title Romeo, doffe thy name,
And for thy name which is no part of thee,
Take all my ſelfe.

speech.speaker: Rom.
speech.line: I take thee at thy word:
Call me but Loue, and Ile be new baptiz’d,
Hence foorth I neuer will be Romeo.

speech.speaker: Iuli.
speech.line: What man art thou, that thus beſcreen’d in night
So ſtumbleſt on my counſell?

speech.speaker: Rom.
speech.line: By a name,
I know not how to tell thee who I am:
My name deare Saint, is hatefull to my ſelfe,
Becauſe it is an Enemy to thee,
Had I it written, I would teare the word.

speech.speaker: Iuli.
speech.line: My eares haue yet not drunke a hundred words
Of thy tongues vttering, yet I know the ſound.
Art thou not Romeo, and a Montague?

speech.speaker: Rom.
speech.line: Neither faire Maid, if either thee diſlike.

speech.speaker: Iul.
speech.line: How cam’ſt thou hither.
Tell me, and wherefore?
The Orchard walls are high, and hard to climbe,
And the place death, conſidering who thou art,
If any of my kinſmen find thee here.

speech.speaker: Rom.
speech.line: With Loues light wings
Did I ore-perch theſe Walls,
For ſtony limits cannot hold Loue out,
And what Loue can do, that dares Loue attempt:
Therefore thy kinſmen are no ſtop to me.

speech.speaker: Iul.
speech.line: If they do ſee thee, they will murther thee.

speech.speaker: Rom.
speech.line: Alacke there lies more perill in thine eye,
Then twenty of their Swords, looke thou but ſweete,
And I am proofe againſt their enmity.

speech.speaker: Iul.
speech.line: I would not for the world they ſaw thee here.

speech.speaker: Rom.
speech.line: I haue nights cloake to hide me from their eyes
And but thou loue me, let them finde me here,
My life were better ended by their hate,
Then death proroged wanting of thy Loue.

speech.speaker: Iul.
speech.line: By whoſe direƈtion found’ſt thou out this place?

speech.speaker: Rom.
speech.line: By Loue that firſt did prompt me to enquire,
He lent me counſell, and I lent him eyes,
I am no Pylot, yet wert thou as far
As that vast-ſhore-waſhet with the fartheſt Sea,
I ſhould aduenture for ſuch Marchandiſe.

speech.speaker: Iul.
speech.line: Thou knoweſt the maske of night is on my face,
Elſe would a Maiden bluſh bepaint my cheeke,
For that which thou haſt heard me ſpeake to night,
Faine would I dwell on forme, faine, faine, denie
What I haue ſpoke, but farewell Complement,
Doeſt thou Loue? I know thou wilt ſay I,
And I will take thy word, yet if thou ſwear’ſt,
Thou maieſt proue falſe: at Louers periuries
They ſay Ioue laught, oh gentle Romeo,
If thou doſt Loue, pronounce it faithfully:
Or if thou thinkeſt I am too quickly wonne,
Ile frowne and be peruerſe, and ſay thee nay,
So thou wilt wooe: But elſe not for the world.
In truth faire Mountague I am too fond:
And therefore thou maieſt thinke my behauiour light,
But truſt me Gentleman, Ile proue more true,
Then thoſe that haue coying to be ſtrange,
I ſhould haue beene more ſtrange, I muſt confeſſe,
But that thou ouer heard’ſt ere I was ware
My true Loues paſſion, therefore pardon me,
And not impute this yeelding to light Loue,
Which the darke night hath ſo diſcouered.

speech.speaker: Rom.
speech.line: Lady, by yonder Moone I vow,
That tips with ſiluer all theſe Fruite tree tops.

speech.speaker: Iul.
speech.line: O ſweare not by the Moone, th’ inconſtant Moone,
That monethly changes in her circled Orbe,
Leaſt that thy Loue proue likewiſe variable.

speech.speaker: Rom.
speech.line: What ſhall I ſweare by?

speech.speaker: Iul.
speech.line: Do not ſweare at all:
Or if thou wilt ſweare by thy gratious ſelfe,
Which is the God of my Idolatry,
And Ile beleeue thee.

speech.speaker: Rom.
speech.line: If my hearts deare loue.

speech.speaker: Iuli.
speech.line: Well do not ſweare, although I ioy in thee:
I haue no ioy of this contraƈt to night,
It is too raſh, too vnaduiſ’d, too ſudden,
Too like the lightning which doth ceaſe to be
Ere, one can ſay, it lightens, Sweete good night:
This bud of Loue by Summers ripening breath,
May proue a beautious Flower when next we meete:
Goodnight, goodnight, as ſweete repoſe and reſt,
Come to thy heart, as that within my breſt.

speech.speaker: Rom.
speech.line: O wilt thou leaue me ſo vnſatisfied?

speech.speaker: Iuli.
speech.line: What ſatisfaƈtion can’ſt thou haue to night?

speech.speaker: Ro.
speech.line: Th’ exchange of thy Loues faithfull vow for mine.

speech.speaker: Iul.
speech.line: I gaue thee mine before thou did’ſt requeſt it:
And yet I would it were to giue againe.

speech.speaker: Rom.
speech.line: Would’ſt thou withdraw it,
For what purpoſe Loue?

speech.speaker: Iul.
speech.line: But to be franke and giue it thee againe,
And yet I wiſh but for the thing I haue,
My bounty is as boundleſſe as the Sea,
My Loue as deepe, the more I giue to thee
The more I haue, for both are Infinite:
I heare ſome noyſe within deare Loue adue:
Anon good Nurſe, ſweet Mountague be true:
Stay but a little, I will come againe.

speech.speaker: Rom.
speech.line: O bleſſed bleſſed night, I am afear’d
Being in night, all this is but a dreame,
Too flattering ſweet to be ſubſtantiall.

speech.speaker: Iul.
speech.line: Three words deare Romeo,
And goodnight indeed,
If that thy bent of Loue be Honourable,
Thy purpoſe marriage, ſend me word to morrow,
By one that Ile procure to come to thee,
Where and what time thou wilt performe the right,
And all my Fortunes at thy foote Ile lay,
And follow thee my Lord throughout the world.
Within:Madam.
I come, anon: but if thou meaneſt not well,
I do beſeech thee
Within:Madam.
(By and by I come)
To ceaſe thy ſtrife, and leaue me to my griefe,
To morrow will I ſend.

speech.speaker: Rom.
speech.line: So thriue my ſoule.

speech.speaker: Iu.
speech.line: A thouſand times goodnight.

speech.speaker: Rome.
speech.line: A thouſand times the worſe to want thy light,
Loue goes toward Loue as ſchool-boyes frō thier books
But Loue frō Loue, towards ſchoole with heauie lookes.

speech.speaker: Iul.
speech.line: Hiſt Romeo hiſt: O for a Falkners voice,
To lure this Taſſell gentle backe againe,
Bondage is hoarſe, and may not ſpeake aloud,
Elſe would I teare the Caue where Eccho lies,
And make her ayrie tongue more hoarſe, then
With repetition of my Romeo.

speech.speaker: Rom.
speech.line: It is my ſoule that calls vpon my name.
How ſiluer ſweet, ſound Louers tongues by night,
Like ſofteſt Muſicke to attending eares.

speech.speaker: Rom.
speech.line: My Neece.

speech.speaker: Iul.
speech.line: What a clock to morrow
Shall I ſend to thee?

speech.speaker: Rom.
speech.line: By the houre of nine.

speech.speaker: Iul.
speech.line: I will not faile, ‘tis twenty yeares till then,
I haue forgot why I did call thee backe.

speech.speaker: Rom.
speech.line: Let me ſtand here till thou remember it.

speech.speaker: Iul.
speech.line: I ſhall forget, to haue thee ſtill ſtand there,
Remembring how I Loue thy company.

speech.speaker: Rom.
speech.line: And Ile ſtill ſtay, to haue thee ſtill forget,
Forgetting any other home but this.

speech.speaker: Iul.
speech.line: ‘Tis almoſt morning, I would haue thee gone,
And yet no further then a wantons Bird,
That let’s it hop a little from his hand,
Like a poore priſoner in his twiſted Gyues,
And with a ſilken thred plucks it backe againe,
So louing Iealous of his liberty.

speech.speaker: Rom.
speech.line: I would I were thy Bird.

speech.speaker: Iul.
speech.line: Sweet ſo would I,
Yet I ſhould kill thee with much cheriſhing:
Good night, good night.

speech.speaker: Rom.
speech.line: Parting is ſuch ſweete ſorrow,
That I ſhall ſay goodnight, till it be morrow.

speech.speaker: Iul.
speech.line: Sleepe dwell vpon thine eyes, peace in thy breſt.

speech.speaker: Rom.
speech.line: Would I were ſleepe and peace ſo ſweet to reſt,
The gray ey’d morne ſmiles on the frowning night,
Checkring the Eaſterne Clouds with ſtreakes of light,
And darkeneſſe fleckel’d like a drunkard reeles,
From forth dayes pathway, made by Titans wheeles.
Hence will I to my ghoſtly Friers cloſe Cell,
His helpe to craue, and my deare hap to tell.

scene.stagedir: Enter Frier alone with a basket.

speech.speaker: Fri.
speech.line: The gray ey’d morne ſmiles on the frowning night,
Checkring the Eaſterne Cloudes with ſtreaks of light:
And fleckled darkneſſe like a drunkard reeles,
From forth daies path, and Titans burning wheeles:
Now ere the Sun aduance his burning eye,
The day to cheere, and nights danke dew to dry,
I muſt vpfill this Oſier Cage of ours,
With balefull weedes, and precious Iuiced flowers,
The earth that’s Natures mother, is her Tombe,
What is her burying graue that is her wombe:
And from her wombe children of diuers kind
We ſucking on her naturall boſome find:
Many for many vertues excellent:
None but for ſome, and yet all different.
O mickle is the powerfull grace that lies
In Plants, Hearbs, ſtones, and their true qualities:
For nought ſo vile, that on earth doth liue,
But to the earth ſome ſpeciall good doth giue.
Nor ought ſo good, but ſtrain’d from that faire vſe,
Reuolts from true birth, ſtumbling on abuſe.
Vertue it ſelfe turnes vice being miſapplied,
And vice ſometime by aƈtion dignified.
Within the infant rin’d of this weake flower,
Poyſon hath reſidence, and medicine power:
For this being ſmelt, with that part cheares each part,
Being taſted ſtayes all ſences with the heart.
Two ſuch oppoſed Kings encampe them ſtill,
In man as well as Hearbes grace and rude will:
And where the worſer is predominant,
Full ſoone the Canker death eates vp that Plant.

speech.speaker: Rom.
speech.line: Good morrow Father.

speech.speaker: Fri.
speech.line: Benedecite.
What early tongue ſo ſweet ſaluteth me?
Young Sonne, it argues a diſtempered head,
So ſoone to bid goodmorrow to thy bed;
Care keepes his watch in euery old mans eye,
And where Care lodges, ſleepe will neuer lye:
But where vnbruſed youth with vnſtuft braine
Doth couch his lims, there, golden ſleepe doth raigne;
Therefore thy earlineſſe doth me aſſure,
Thou art vprouſ’d with ſome diſtemprature;
Or if not ſo, then here I hit it right.
Our Romeo hath not beene in bed to night.

speech.speaker: Rom.
speech.line: That laſt is true, the ſweeter reſt was mine.

speech.speaker: Fri.
speech.line: God pardon ſin: waſt thou with Roſaline?

speech.speaker: Rom.
speech.line: With Roſaline, my ghoſtly Father? No,
I haue forgot that name, and that names woe.

speech.speaker: Fri.
speech.line: That's my good Son, but wher haſt thou bin then?

speech.speaker: Rom.
speech.line: Ile tell thee ere thou aske it me agen:
I haue beene feaſting with mine enemie,
Where on a ſudden one hath wounded me,
That’s by me wounded: both our remedies
Within thy helpe and holy phiſicke lies:
I beare no hatred, bleſſed man: for loe
My interceſſion likewiſe ſteads my foe.

speech.speaker: Fri.
speech.line: Be plaine good Son, reſt homely in thy drift,
Ridling confeſſion, findes but ridling ſhrift.

speech.speaker: Rom.
speech.line: Then plainly know my hearts deare Loue is ſet,
On the faire daughter of rich Capulet:
As mine on hers, ſo hers is ſet on mine;
And all combin’d, ſaue what thou muſt combine
By holy marriage: when and where, and how,
We met, we wooed, and made exchange of vow:
Ile tell thee as we paſſe, but this I pray,
That thou conſent to marrie vs to day.

speech.speaker: Fri.
speech.line: Holy S. Francis, what a change is heere?
Is Roſaline that thou didſt Loue ſo deare
So ſoone forſaken? young mens Loue then lies
Not truely in their hearts, but in their eyes.
Iesu Maria, what a deale of brine
Hath waſht thy ſallow cheekes for Roſaline?
How much ſalt water throwne away in waſt,
To ſeaſon Loue that of it doth not taſt.
The Sun not yet thy ſighes, from heauen cleares,
Thy old grones yet ringing in my auncient eares:
Lo here vpon thy cheeke the ſtaine doth ſit,
Of an old teare that is not waſht off yet.
If ere thou waſt thy ſelfe, and theſe woes thine,
Thou and theſe woes, were all for Roſaline.
And art thou chang’d? pronounce this ſentence then,
Women may fall, when there’s no ſtrength in men.

speech.speaker: Rom.
speech.line: Thou chid’ſt me oft for louing Roſaline.

speech.speaker: Fri.
speech.line: For doting, not for louing pupill mine.

speech.speaker: Rom.
speech.line: And bad’ſt me bury Loue.

speech.speaker: Fri.
speech.line: Not in a graue,
To lay one in, another out to haue.

speech.speaker: Rom.
speech.line: I pray thee chide me not, her I Loue now
Doth grace for grace, and Loue for Loue allow:
The other did not ſo.

speech.speaker: Fri.
speech.line: O ſhe knew well,
Thy Loue did read by rote, that could not ſpell:
But come young wauerer, come goe with me,
In one reſpeƈt, Ile thy aſſiſtant be:
For this alliance may ſo happy proue,
To turne your houſhould rancor to pure Loue.

speech.speaker: Rom.
speech.line: O let vs hence, I ſtand on ſudden haſt.

speech.speaker: Fri.
speech.line: Wiſely and ſlow, they ſtumble that run faſt.

speech.speaker: Mer.
speech.line: Where the deule ſhould this Romeo be? came he
not home to night?

speech.speaker: Ben.
speech.line: Not to his Fathers, I ſpoke with his man.

speech.speaker: Mer.
speech.line: Why that ſame pale hard-harted wench, that Ro-
ſaline torments him ſo, that he will ſure run mad.

speech.speaker: Ben.
speech.line: Tibalt, the kinſman to old Capulet, hath ſent a Let—
ter to his Fathers houſe.

speech.speaker: Mer.
speech.line: A challenge on my life.

speech.speaker: Ben.
speech.line: Romeo will answere it.

speech.speaker: Mer.
speech.line: Any man that can write, may anſwere a Letter.

speech.speaker: Ben.
speech.line: Nay, he will anſwere the Letters Maiſter how he
dares, being dared.

speech.speaker: Mer.
speech.line: Alas poore Romeo, he is already dead ſtab’d with
a white wenches blacke eye, runne through the eare with
a Loue ſong, the very pinne of his heart, cleft with the
blind Bowe-boyes but-ſhaft, and is he a man to encounter Tybalt?

speech.speaker: Ben.
speech.line: Why what is Tibalt?

speech.speaker: Mer.
speech.line: More then Prince of Cats. Oh hee’s the Couragi—
ous Captaine of Complements: he fights as you ſing
prickſong, keeps time, diſtance, and proportion, he reſts
his minum, one, two, and the third in your boſom: the ve—
ry butcher of a ſilk button, a Dualiſt, a Dualiſt: a Gentleman
of the very firſt houſe of the firſt and ſecond cauſe: ah the
immortall Paſſado, the Punto reuerſo, the Hay.

speech.speaker: Ben.
speech.line: The what?

speech.speaker: Mer.
speech.line: The Pox of ſuch antique liſping affeƈting phan—
tacies, theſe new tuners of accent: Ieſu a very good blade,
a very tall man, a very good whore. Why is not this a la—
mentable thing Grandſire, that we ſhould be thus affliƈted
with theſe ſtrange flies: theſe faſhion Mongers, theſe par—
don-mee's, who ſtand ſo much on the new form, that they
cannot ſit at eaſe on the old bench. O their bones, their
bones.

speech.speaker: Ben.
speech.line: Here comes Romeo, here comes Romeo.

speech.speaker: Mer.
speech.line: Without his Roe, like a dryed Hering. O fleſh,
fleſh, how art thou fiſhified? Now is he for the numbers
that Petrarch flowed in: Laura to his Lady, was a kitchen
wench, marrie ſhe had a better Loue to berime her: Dido
a dowdie, Cleopatra a Gipſie, Hellen and Hero, hildings
and Harlots: Thisbie a gray eie or ſo, but not to the purpoſe.
Signior Romeo, Bon iour, there's a French ſalutation to your
French ſlop: you gaue vs the counterfait fairely laſt
night.

speech.speaker: Romeo.
speech.line: Good morrow to you both, what counterfeit
did I giue you?

speech.speaker: Mer.
speech.line: The ſlip ſir, the ſlip, can you not conceiue?

speech.speaker: Rom.
speech.line: Pardon Mercutio, my buſineſſe was great, and in
ſuch a caſe as mine, a man may ſtraine curteſie.

speech.speaker: Mer.
speech.line: That's as much as to ſay, ſuch a caſe as yours con—
ſtrains a man to bow in the hams.

speech.speaker: Rom.
speech.line: Meaning to curſie.

speech.speaker: Mer.
speech.line: Thou haſt moſt kindly hit it.

speech.speaker: Rom.
speech.line: A moſt curteous expoſition.

speech.speaker: Mer.
speech.line: Nay, I am the very pinck of curteſie.

speech.speaker: Rom.
speech.line: Pinke for flower.

speech.speaker: Mer.
speech.line: Right.

speech.speaker: Rom.
speech.line: Why then is my Pump well flowr’d.

speech.speaker: Mer.
speech.line: Sure wit, follow me this ieaſt, now till thou haſt
worne out thy Pump, that when the ſingle ſole of it is
worne, the ieaſt may remaine after the wearing, ſole—
ſingular.

speech.speaker: Rom.
speech.line: O ſingle ſol’d ieaſt,
Soly ſingular for the ſingleneſſe.

speech.speaker: Mer.
speech.line: Come betweene vs good Benuolio, my wits faints.

speech.speaker: Rom.
speech.line: Swits and ſpurs,
Swits and ſpurs, or Ile crie a match.

speech.speaker: Mer.
speech.line: Nay, if our wits run the Wild-Gooſe chaſe, I am
done: For thou haſt more of the Wild-Gooſe in one of
thy wits, then I am ſure I haue in my whole fiue. Was I
with you there for the Gooſe?

speech.speaker: Rom.
speech.line: Thou waſt neuer with mee for any thing, when
thou waſt not there for the Gooſe.

speech.speaker: Mer.
speech.line: I will bite thee by the eare for that ieſt.

speech.speaker: Rom.
speech.line: Nay, good Gooſe bite not.

speech.speaker: Mer.
speech.line: Thy wit is a very Bitter-ſweeting,
It is a moſt ſharpe ſawce.

speech.speaker: Rom.
speech.line: And is it not well ſeru’d into a Sweet-Gooſe?

speech.speaker: Mer.
speech.line: Oh here's a wit of Cheuerell, that ſtretches from
an ynch narrow, to an ell broad.

speech.speaker: Rom.
speech.line: I ſtretch it out for that word, broad, which added
to the Gooſe, proues thee farre and wide, abroad Gooſe.

speech.speaker: Mer.
speech.line: Why is not this better now, then groning for
Loue, now art thou ſociable, now art thou Romeo: now art
thou what thou art, by Art as well as by Nature, for this
driueling Loue is like a great Naturall, that runs lolling
vp and downe to hid his bable in a hole.

speech.speaker: Ben.
speech.line: Stop there, ſtop there.

speech.speaker: Mer.
speech.line: Thou deſir’ſt me to ſtop in my tale againſt the haire.

speech.speaker: Ben.
speech.line: Thou would’ſt elſe haue made thy tale large.

speech.speaker: Mer.
speech.line: O thou art deceiu’d, I would haue made it ſhort,
or I was come to the whole depth of my tale, and meant
indeed to occupie the argument no longer.

speech.speaker: Rom.
speech.line: Here's a goodly geare.
A ſayle, a ſayle.

speech.speaker: Mer.
speech.line: Two, two: a Shirt and a Smocke.

speech.speaker: Nur.
speech.line: Peter?

speech.speaker: Peter.
speech.line: Anon.

speech.speaker: Nur.
speech.line: My Fan Peter?

speech.speaker: Mer.
speech.line: Good Peter to hide her face?
For her Fans the fairer face?

speech.speaker: Nur.
speech.line: God ye good morrow Gentlemen.

speech.speaker: Mer.
speech.line: God ye gooden faire Gentlewoman.

speech.speaker: Nur.
speech.line: Is it gooden?

speech.speaker: Mer.
speech.line: ‘Tis no leſſe I tell you: for the bawdy hand of the
Dyall is now vpon the pricke of Noone.

speech.speaker: Nur.
speech.line: Out vpon you: what a man are you?

speech.speaker: Rom.
speech.line: One Gentlewoman,
That God hath made, himſelfe to mar.

speech.speaker: Nur.
speech.line: By my troth it is ſaid, for himſelfe to, mar qua—
tha: Gentlemen, can any of you tel me where I may find
the young Romeo?

speech.speaker: Romeo.
speech.line: I can tell you: but young Romeo will be older
when you haue found him, then he was when you ſought
him: I am the youngeſt of that name, for fault of a worſe.

speech.speaker: Nur.
speech.line: You ſay well.

speech.speaker: Mer.
speech.line: Yea is the worſt well,
Very well tooke: Ifaith, wiſely, wiſely.

speech.speaker: Nur.
speech.line: If you be he ſir,
I deſire ſome confidence with you?

speech.speaker: Ben.
speech.line: She will endite him to ſome Supper.

speech.speaker: Mer.
speech.line: A baud, a baud, a baud. So ho.

speech.speaker: Rom.
speech.line: What haſt thou found?

speech.speaker: Mer.
speech.line: No Hare ſir, vnleſſe a Hare ſir in a Lenten pie,
that is ſomething ſtale and hoare ere it be ſpent.
An old Hare hoare, and an old Hare hoare is very good
meat in Lent.
But a Hare that is hoare is too much for a ſcore, when it
hoares ere it be ſpent,
Romeo will you come to your Fathers? Weele to dinner
thither.

speech.speaker: Rom.
speech.line: I will follow you.

speech.speaker: Mer.
speech.line: Farewell auncient Lady:
Farewell Lady, Lady, Lady.

speech.speaker: Nur.
speech.line: I pray you ſir, what ſawcie Merchant was this
that was ſo full of his roperie?

speech.speaker: Rom.
speech.line: A Gentleman Nurſe, that loues to heare himſelfe
talke, and will ſpeake more in a minute, then he will ſtand
to in a Moneth.

speech.speaker: Nur.
speech.line: And a ſpeake any thing againſt me, Ile take him
downe, & a were luſtier then he is, and twentie ſuch lacks:
and if I cannot, Ile finde thoſe that ſhall: ſcuruie knaue, I
am none of his flurt-gils, I am none of his skaines mates,
and thou muſt ſtand by too and ſuffer euery knaue to vſe
me at his pleaſure.

speech.speaker: Pet.
speech.line: I ſaw no man vſe you at his pleaſure: if I had, my
weapon ſhould quickly haue beene out, I warrant you, I
dare draw aſſoone as another man, if I ſee occaſion in a
good quarrell, and the law on my ſide.

speech.speaker: Nur.
speech.line: Now afore God, I am ſo vext, that euery part about
me quiuers, ſkuruy knaue: pray you ſir a word: and as I
told you, my young Lady bid me enquire you out, what
ſhe bid me ſay, I will keepe to my ſelfe: but firſt let me
tell ye, if ye ſhould leade her in a fooles paradiſe, as they
ſay, it were a very groſſe kind of behauiour, as they ſay:
for the Gentlewoman is yong: & therefore, if you ſhould
deale double with her, truely it were an ill thing to be of—
fered to any Gentlewoman, and very weake dealing.

speech.speaker: Nur.
speech.line: Nurſe commend me to thy Lady and Miſtreſſe, I
proteſt vnto thee.

speech.speaker: Nur.
speech.line: Good heart, and yfaith I will tell her as much:
Lord, Lord ſhe will be a ioyfull woman.

speech.speaker: Rom.
speech.line: What wilt thou tell her Nurſe? thou doeſt not
marke me?

speech.speaker: Nur.
speech.line: I will tell her ſir, that you do proteſt, which as I
take it, is a Gentleman-like offer.

speech.speaker: Rom.
speech.line: Bid her deuiſe ſome meanes to come to ſhrift this afternoone,
And there ſhe ſhall at Frier Lawrence Cell
Be ſhriu’d and married: here is for thy paines.

speech.speaker: Nur.
speech.line: No truly ſir not a penny.

speech.speaker: Rom.
speech.line: Go too, I ſay you ſhall.

speech.speaker: Nur.
speech.line: This afternoone ſir? well ſhe ſhall be there.

speech.speaker: Ro.
speech.line: And ſtay thou good Nurſe behind the Abbey wall,
Within this houre my man ſhall be with thee,
And bring thee Cords made like a tackled ſtaire,
Which to the high top gallant of my ioy,
Muſt be my conuoy in the ſecret night.
Farewell, be truſtie and Ile quite thy paines:
Farewell, commend me to thy Miſtreſſe.

speech.speaker: Nur.
speech.line: Now God in heauen bleſſe thee: harke you ſir.

speech.speaker: Rom.
speech.line: What ſaiſt thou my deare Nurſe?

speech.speaker: Nurſe.
speech.line: Is your man ſecret, did you nere heare ſay two
may keepe counſell putting one away.

speech.speaker: Ro.
speech.line: Warrant thee my man is true as ſteele.

speech.speaker: Nur.
speech.line: Well ſir, my Miſtreſſe is the ſweeteſt Lady, Lord,
Lord, when ’twas a little prating thing. O there is a No—
ble man in Towne one Paris, that would faine lay knife a—
board: but ſhe good ſoule had as leeue ſee a Toade, a very
Toade as ſee him: I anger her ſometimes, and tell her that
Paris is the properer man, but Ile warrant you, when I ſay
ſo, ſhee lookes as pale as any clout in the verſall world.
Doth not Roſemarie and Romeo begin both with a letter?

speech.speaker: Rom.
speech.line: I Nurſe, what of that? Both with an R

speech.speaker: Nur.
speech.line: A mocker that’s the dogs name. R. is for the no,
I know it begins with ſome other letter, and ſhe hath the
prettieſt ſententious of it, of you and Roſemary, that it
would do you good to heare it.

speech.speaker: Rom.
speech.line: Commend me to thy Lady.

speech.speaker: Nur.
speech.line: I a thouſand times. Peter?

speech.speaker: Pet.
speech.line: Anon.

speech.speaker: Nur.
speech.line: Before and apace.

speech.speaker: Iul.
speech.line: The clocke ſtrook nine, when I did ſend the Nurſe,
In halfe an houre ſhe promised to returne,
Perchance ſhe cannot meete him: that’s not ſo:
Oh ſhe is lame, Loues Herauld ſhould be thoughts,
Which ten times faſter glides then the Sunnes beames,
Driuing backe ſhadowes ouer lowring hils.
Therefore do nimble Pinion’d Doues draw Loue,
And therefore hath the wind-ſwift Cupid wings:
Now is the Sun vpon the highmoſt hill
Of this daies iourney, and from nine till twelue,
I three long houres, yet ſhe is not come.
Had ſhe affeƈtions and warme youthfull blood,
She would be as ſwift in motion as a ball,
My words would bandy her to my ſweete Loue,
And his to me, but old folkes,
Many faine as they were dead,
Vnwieldie, ſlow, heauy, and pale as lead.
O God ſhe comes, O hony Nurſe what newes?
Haſt thou met with him? ſend thy man away.

speech.speaker: Nur.
speech.line: Peter ſtay at the gate.

speech.speaker: Iul.
speech.line: Now good ſweet Nurſe:
O Lord, why lookeſt thou ſad?
Though newes, be ſad, yet tell them merrily.
If good thou ſham’ſt the muſicke of ſweet newes,
By playing it to me, with ſo ſower a face.

speech.speaker: Nur.
speech.line: I am a weary, giue me leaue awhile,
Fie how my bones ake, what a iaunt haue I had?

speech.speaker: Iul.
speech.line: I would thou had’ſt my bones, and I thy newes:
Nay come I pray thee ſpeake, good good Nurſe ſpeake.

speech.speaker: Nur.
speech.line: Iesu what haſt? can you not ſtay a while?
Do you not ſee that I am out of breath?

speech.speaker: Iul.
speech.line: How art thou out of breath, when thou haſt breth
To ſay to me, that thou art out of breath?
The excuſe that thou doſt make in this delay,
Is longer then the tale thou doſt excuſe.
Is thy newes good or bad? anſwere to that,
Say either, and Ile ſtay the circumſtance:
Let me be ſatisfied, iſt good or bad?

speech.speaker: Nur.
speech.line: Well, you haue made a ſimple choice, you know
not how to chuſe a man: Romeo, no not he though his face
be better then any mans, yet his legs excels all mens, and
for a hand, and a foote, and a body, though they be not to
be talkt on, yet they are paſt compare: he is not the flower
of curteſie, but Ile warrant him as gentle a Lambe: go thy
waies wench, ſerue God. What haue you din’d at home?

speech.speaker: Iul.
speech.line: No no: but all this did I know before
What ſaies he of our marriage? what of that?

speech.speaker: Nur.
speech.line: Lord how my head akes, what a head haue I?
It beates as it would fall in twenty peeces.
My backe a tother ſide: o my backe, my backe:
Beſhrew your heart for ſending me about
To catch my death with iaunting vp and downe.

speech.speaker: Iul.
speech.line: Ifaith: I am ſorrie that thou art ſo well.
Sweet ſweet, ſweet Nurſe, tell me what ſaies my Loue?

speech.speaker: Nur.
speech.line: Your Loue ſaies like an honeſt Gentleman,
And a courteous, and a kind, and a handſome,
And I warrant a vertuous: where is your Mother?

speech.speaker: Iul.
speech.line: Where is my Mother?
Why ſhe is within, where ſhould ſhe be?
How odly thou repli’ſt:
Your Loue ſaies like an honeſt Gentleman:
Where is your Mother?

speech.speaker: Nur.
speech.line: O Gods Lady deare,
Are you ſo hot? marrie come vp I trow,
Is this the Poultis for my aking bones?
Henceforward do your meſſages your ſelfe.

speech.speaker: Iul.
speech.line: Heere’s ſuch a coile, come what ſaies Romeo?

speech.speaker: Nur.
speech.line: Haue you got leaue to go to ſhrift to day?

speech.speaker: Iul.
speech.line: I haue.

speech.speaker: Nur.
speech.line: Then high you hence to Frier Lawrence Cell,
There ſtaies a Husband to make you a wife:
Now comes the wanton bloud vp in your cheekes,
Thei’le be in Scarlet ſtraight at any newes:
Hie you to Church, I muſt an other way,
To fetch a Ladder by the which your Loue
Muſt climde a birds neſt Soone when it is darke:
I am the drudge, and toile in your delight:
But you ſhall beare the burthen ſoone at night.
Go Ile to dinner, hie you to the Cell.

speech.speaker: Iul
speech.line: Hie to high Fortune, honeſt Nurſe, farewell.

speech.speaker: Fri.
speech.line: So ſmile the heauens vpon this holy aƈt,
That after houres, with ſorrow chide vs not.

speech.speaker: Rom.
speech.line: Amen, amen, but come what ſorrow can,
It cannot counteruaile the exchange of ioy
That one ſhort minute giues me in her ſight:
Do thou but cloſe our hands with holy words.
Then Loue-deuouring death do what he dare,
It is inough. I may call her mine.

speech.speaker: Fri.
speech.line: Theſe violent delights haue violent endes,
And in their triumph: die like fire and powder;
Which as they kiſſe conſume. The ſweeteſt honey
Is loathſome in his owne deliciouſneſſe,
And in the taſte confoundes the appetite.
Therefore Loue moderately, long Loue doth ſo,
Too ſwift arriues as tardie as too ſlow.
Here comes the Lady. Oh ſo light a foot
Will nere weare out the euerlaſting flint,
A Louer may bestride the Goſſamours,
That ydles in the wanton Summer ayre,
And yet not fall, ſo light is vanitie.

speech.speaker: Iul.
speech.line: Good euen to my ghoſtly Confeſſor.

speech.speaker: Fri.
speech.line: Romeo ſhall thanke thee Daughter for vs both.

speech.speaker: Iul.
speech.line: As much to him, elſe in his thanks too much.

speech.speaker: Fri.
speech.line: Ah Iuliet, if the meaſure of thy ioy
Be heapt like mine, and that thy skill be more
To blaſon it, then ſweeten with thy breath
This neighbour ayre, and let rich muſickes tongue,
Vnfold the imagin’d happineſſe that both
Receiue in either, by this deere encounter.

speech.speaker: Iul.
speech.line: Conceit more rich in matter then in words,
Brags of his ſubſtance, not of Ornament:
They are but beggers that can count their worth,
But my true Loue is growne to ſuch ſuch exceſſe,
I cannot ſum vp ſome of halfe my wealth.

speech.speaker: Fri.
speech.line: Come, come with me, & we will make ſhort worke,
For by your leaues, you ſhall not ſtay alone,
Till holy Church incorporate two in one.

speech.speaker: Ben.
speech.line: I pray thee good Mercutio lets retire,
The day is hot, the Capulets abroad:
And if we meet, we ſhal not ſcape a brawle, for now theſe
hot dayes, is the mad blood ſtirring.

speech.speaker: Mer.
speech.line: Thou art like one of theſe fellowes, that when he
enters the confines of a Tauerne, claps me his Sword vpon
the Table, and ſayes, God ſend me no need of thee: and by
the operation of the ſecond cup, drawes him on the Draw—
er, when indeed there is no need.

speech.speaker: Ben.
speech.line: Am I like ſuch a Fellow?

speech.speaker: Mer.
speech.line: Come, come, thou art as hot a Iacke in thy mood,
as any in Italie: and aſſoone moued to be moodie, and aſ—
ſoone moodie to be mou’d.

speech.speaker: Ben.
speech.line: And what too?

speech.speaker: Mer.
speech.line: Nay, and there were two ſuch, we ſhould haue
none ſhortly, for one would kill the other: thou, why thou
wilt quarrell with a man that hath a haire more, or a haire
leſſe in his beard, then thou haſt: thou wilt quarrell with a
man for cracking Nuts, hauing no other reaſon, but be—
cauſe thou haſt haſell eyes: what eye, but ſuch an eye,
would ſpie out ſuch a quarrell? thy head is full of quar—
rels, as an egge is full of meat, and yet thy head hath bin
beaten as addle as an egge for quarreling: thou haſt quar—
rel’d with a man for coffing in the ſtreet, becauſe he hath
wakened thy Dog that hath laine aſleepe in the Sun. Did’ſt
thou not fall out with a Tailor for wearing his new Doub—
let before Eaſter? with another, for tying his new ſhooes
with old Riband, and yet thou wilt Tutor me from quar—
relling?

speech.speaker: Ben.
speech.line: And I were ſo apt to quarell as thou art, any man
ſhould buy the Fee-ſimple of my life, for an houre and a
quarter.

speech.speaker: Mer.
speech.line: The Fee-ſimple? O ſimple.

speech.speaker: Ben.
speech.line: By my head here comes the Capulets.

speech.speaker: Mer.
speech.line: By my heele I care not.

speech.speaker: Tyb.
speech.line: Follow me cloſe, for I will ſpeake to them.
Gentlemen, Good den, a word with one of you.

speech.speaker: Mer.
speech.line: And but one word with one of vs? couple it with
ſomething, make it a word and a blow.

speech.speaker: Tib.
speech.line: You ſhall find me apt inough to that ſir, and you
will giue me occaſion.

speech.speaker: Mercu.
speech.line: Could you not take ſome occaſion without
giuing?

speech.speaker: Tib.
speech.line: Mercutio thou conſort’ſt with Romeo.

speech.speaker: Mer.
speech.line: Conſort? what doſt thou make vs Minſtrels? &
thou make Minſtrels of vs, looke to heare nothing but diſ—
cords: heere's my fiddleſticke, heere's that ſhall make you
daunce. Come conſort.

speech.speaker: Ben.
speech.line: We talke here in the publike haunt of men,
Either withdraw vnto ſome priuate place,
Or reaſon coldly of your greeuances:
Or elſe depart, here all eies gaze on vs.

speech.speaker: Mer.
speech.line: Mens eyes were made to looke, and let them gaze.
I will not budge for no mans pleaſure I.

speech.speaker: Tib.
speech.line: Well peace be with you ſir, here comes my man.

speech.speaker: Mer.
speech.line: But Ile be hang’d ſir if he weare your Liuery.
Marry go before to field, heele be your follower,
Your worſhip in that ſense, may call him man.

speech.speaker: Tib.
speech.line: Romeo, the loue I beare thee, can affoord
No better terme then this: Thou art a Villaine.

speech.speaker: Rom.
speech.line: Tibalt, the reaſon that I haue to loue thee,
Doth much excuſe the appertaining rage
To ſuch a greeting: Villaine am I none;
Therefore farewell, I ſee thou know’ſt me not.

speech.speaker: Tib.
speech.line: Boy, this ſhall not excuſe the iniuries
That thou haſt done me, therefore turne and draw.

speech.speaker: Rom.
speech.line: I do proteſt I neuer iniur’d thee,
But lou’d thee better then thou can’ſt deuiſe:
Till thou ſhalt know the reaſon of my loue,
And ſo good Capulet, which name I tender
As dearely as my owne, be ſatisfied.

speech.speaker: Mer.
speech.line: O calme, diſhonourable, vile ſubmiſſion:
Alla stucatho carries it away.
Tybalt, you Rat-catcher, will you walke?

speech.speaker: Tib.
speech.line: What woulds thou haue with me?

speech.speaker: Mer.
speech.line: Good King of Cats, nothing but one of your nine
liues, that I meane to make bold withall, and as you ſhall
vſe me hereafter dry beate the reſt of the eight. Will you
pluck your Sword out of his Pilcher by the eares? Make
haſt, leaſt mine be about your eares ere it be out.

speech.speaker: Tib.
speech.line: I am for you.

speech.speaker: Rom.
speech.line: Gentle Mercutio, put thy Rapier vp.

speech.speaker: Mer.
speech.line: Come ſir, your Paſſado.

speech.speaker: Rom.
speech.line: Draw Benuolio, beat downe their weapons:
Gentlemen, for ſhame forbeare this outrage,
Tibalt, Mercutio, the Prince expreſly hath
Forbidden bandying in Verona ſtreetes.
Hold Tybalt, good Mercutio.

speech.speaker: Mer.
speech.line: I am hurt.
A plague a both the Houſes, I am ſped:
Is he gone and hath nothing?

speech.speaker: Ben.
speech.line: What art thou hurt?

speech.speaker: Mer.
speech.line: I, I, a ſcratch, a ſcratch, marry ‘tis inough,
Where is my Page? go Villaine fetch a Surgeon.

speech.speaker: Rom.
speech.line: Courage man, the hurt cannot be much.

speech.speaker: Mer.
speech.line: No: ‘tis not ſo deepe as a well, nor ſo wide as a
Church doore, but ‘tis inough, ‘twill ſerue: aske for me to
morrow, and you ſhall find me a graue man. I am pepper’d
I warrant, for this world: a plague a both your houſes.
What, a Dog, a Rat, a Mouſe, a Cat to ſcratch a man to
death: a Braggart, a Rogue, a Villaine, that fights by the
booke of Arithmeticke, why the deu’le came you be—
tweene vs? I was hurt vnder your arme.

speech.speaker: Rom.
speech.line: I thought all for the beſt.

speech.speaker: Mer.
speech.line: Helpe me into ſome houſe Benuolio,
Or I ſhall faint: a plague a both your houſes.
They haue made wormesmeat of me,
I haue it, and ſoundly to your Houſes.

speech.speaker: Rom.
speech.line: This Gentleman the Princes neere Alie,
My very Friend hath got his mortall hurt
In my behalfe, my reputation ſtain’d
With Tibalts ſlaunder, Tybalt that an houre
Hath beene my Cozin: O Sweet Iuliet,
Thy Beauty hath made me Effeminate,
And in my temper ſoftned Valours ſteele.

speech.speaker: Ben.
speech.line: O Romeo, Romeo, braue Mercutio's is dead,
That Gallant ſpirit hath aſpir’d the Cloudes,
