Which too vntimely here did ſcorne the earth.

speech.speaker: Rom.
speech.line: This daies blacke Fate, on mo daies doth depend,
This but begins, the wo others muſt end.

speech.speaker: Ben.
speech.line: Here comes the Furious Tybalt backe againe.

speech.speaker: Rom.
speech.line: He gon in triumph, and Mercutio ſlaine?
Away to heauen reſpeƈtiue Lenitie,
And fire and Fury, be my conduƈt now.
Now Tybalt take the Villaine backe againe
That late thou gau’ſt me, for Mercutios ſoule
Is but a little way aboue our heads,
Staying for thine to keepe him companie:
Either thou or I, or both, muſt goe with him.

speech.speaker: Tib.
speech.line: Thou wretched Boy that didſt conſort him here,
Shalt with him hence.

speech.speaker: Rom.
speech.line: This ſhall determine that.

speech.speaker: Ben.
speech.line: Romeo, away be gone:
The Citizens are vp, and Tybalt ſlaine,
Stand not amaz’d, the Prince will Doome thee death
If thou art taken: hence, be gone, away.

speech.speaker: Rom.
speech.line: O! I am Fortunes foole.

speech.speaker: Ben.
speech.line: Why doſt thou ſtay?

speech.speaker: Citi.
speech.line: Which way ran he that kild Mercutio?
Tibalt that Murtherer, which way ran he?

speech.speaker: Ben.
speech.line: There lies that Tybalt.

speech.speaker: Citi.
speech.line: Vp ſir go with me:
I charge thee in the Princes names obey.

scene.stagedir: Enter Prince, old Montague, Capulet, their Wiues and all.

speech.speaker: Prin.
speech.line: Where are the vile beginners of this Fray?

speech.speaker: Ben.
speech.line: O Noble Prince, I can diſcouer all
The vnluckie Mannage of this fatall brall:
There lies the man ſlaine by young Romeo,
That ſlew thy kinſman braue Mercutio.

speech.speaker: Cap. Wi.
speech.line: Tybalt, my Cozin? O my Brothers Child,
O Prince, O Cozin, Husband, O the blood is ſpild
Of my deare kinſman. Prince as thou art true,
For bloud of ours, ſhed bloud of Mountague.
O Cozin, Cozin.

speech.speaker: Prin.
speech.line: Benuolio, who began this Fray?

speech.speaker: Ben.
speech.line: Tybalt here ſlaine, whom Romeo's hand did ſlay,
Romeo that ſpoke him faire, bid him bethinke
How nice the Quarrell was, and vrg’d withall
Your high diſpleaſure: all this vttered,
With gentle breath, calme looke, knees humbly bow’d
Could not take truce with the vnruly ſpleene
Of Tybalts deafe to peace, but that he Tilts
With Peircing ſteele at bold Mercutio's breaſt,
Who all as hot, turnes deadly point to point,
And with a Martiall ſcorne, with one hand beates
Cold death aſide, and with the other ſends
It back to Tybalt, whoſe dexterity
Retorts it: Romeo he cries aloud,
Hold Friends, Friends part, and ſwifter then his tongue,
His aged arme, beats downe their fatall points,
And twixt them ruſhes, vnderneath whoſe arme,
An enuious thruſt from Tybalt, hit the life
Of ſtout Mercutio, and then Tybalt fled.
But by and by comes backe to Romeo,
Who had but newly entertained Reuenge,
And too’t they goe like lightning, for ere I
Could draw to part them, was ſtout Tybalt ſlaine:
And as he fell, did Romeo turne and flie:
This is the truth, or let Benuolio die.

speech.speaker: Cap. Wi.
speech.line: He is a kinſman to the Mountague,
Affeƈtion makes him falſe, he ſpeakes not true:
Some twenty of them fought in this blacke ſtrife,
And all thoſe twenty could but kill one life.
I beg for Iuſtice, which thou Prince muſt giue:
Romeo ſlew Tybalt, Romeo muſt not liue.

speech.speaker: Prin.
speech.line: Romeo ſlew him, he ſlew Mercutio,
Who now the price of his deare blood doth owe.

speech.speaker: Cap.
speech.line: Not Romeo Prince, he was Mercutios Friend,
His fault concludes, but what the law ſhould end,
The life of Tybalt.

speech.speaker: Prin.
speech.line: And for that offence,
Immediately we doe exile him hence:
I haue an intereſt in your hearts proceeding:
My bloud for your rude brawles doth lie a bleeding.
But Ile Amerce you with ſo ſtrong a fine,
That you ſhall all repent the loſſe of mine.
It will be deafe to pleading and excuſes,
Nor teares, nor prayers ſhall purchaſe our abuſes.
Therefore vſe none, let Romeo hence in haſt,
Elſe when he is found, that houre is his laſt.
Beare hence this body, and attend our will:
Mercy not Murders, pardoning thoſe that kill.

speech.speaker: Iul.
speech.line: Gallop apace, you fiery footed ſteedes,
Towards Phœbus lodging, ſuch a Wagoner
As Phaeton would whip you to the weſt,
And bring in Cloudie night immediately.
Spred thy cloſe Curtaine Loue-performing night,
That run-awayes eyes may wincke, and Romeo
Leape to these armes, vntalkt of and vnſeene,
Louers can ſee to doe their Amorous rights,
And by their owne Beauties: or if Loue be blind,
It beſt agrees with night: come ciuill night,
Thou ſober ſuted Matron all in blacke,
And learne me how to looſe a winning match,
Plaid for a paire of ſtainleſſe Maidenhoods,
Hood my vnman’d blood bayting in my Cheekes,
With thy Blacke mantle, till ſtrange Loue grow bold,
Thinke true Loue aƈted ſimple modeſtie:
Come night, come Romeo, come thou day in night,
For thou wilt lie vpon the wings of night
Whiter then new Snow vpon a Rauens backe:
Come gentle night, come louing blackebrow’d night.
Giue me my Romeo, and when I ſhall die,
Take him and cut him out in little ſtarres,
And he will make the Face of heauen ſo fine,
That all the world will be in Loue with night,
And pay no worſhip to the Gariſh Sun.
O I haue bought the Manſion of a Loue,
But not poſſeſt it, and though I am ſold,
Not yet enioy’d, ſo tedious is this day,
As is the night before ſome Feſtiuall,
To an impatient child that hath new robes
And may not weare them, O here comes my Nurſe:
And ſhe brings newes and euery tongue that ſpeaks
But Romeos name, ſpeakes heauenly eloquence:
Now Nurſe, what newes? what haſt thou there?
The Cords that Romeo bid thee fetch?

speech.speaker: Nur.
speech.line: I, I, the Cords.

speech.speaker: Iuli.
speech.line: Ay me, what newes?
Why doſt thou wring thy hands.

speech.speaker: Nur.
speech.line: A welady, hee’s dead, hee’s dead,
We are vndone Lady, we are vndone.
Alacke the day, hee’s gone, hee’s kil’d, he’s dead.

speech.speaker: Iul.
speech.line: Can heauen be ſo enuious?

speech.speaker: Nur.
speech.line: Romeo can,
Though heauen cannot. O Romeo, Romeo.
Who euer would haue thought it Romeo.

speech.speaker: Iuli.
speech.line: What diuell art thou,
That doſt torment me thus?
This torture ſhould be roar’d in diſmall hell,
Hath Romeo ſlaine himſelfe? ſay thou but I,
And that bare vowell I ſhall poyſon more
Then the death-darting eye of Cockatrice,
I am not I, if there be ſuch an I.
Or thoſe eyes ſhot, that makes thee anſwere I:
If he be ſlaine ſay I, or if not, no.
Briefe, ſounds, determine of my weale or wo.

speech.speaker: Nur.
speech.line: I ſaw the wound, I ſaw it with mine eyes,
God ſaue the marke, here on his manly breſt,
A pitteous Coarſe, a bloody piteous Coarſe:
Pale, pale as aſhes, all bedawb’d in blood,
All in gore blood I ſounded at the ſight.

speech.speaker: Iul.
speech.line: O breake my heart,
Poore Banckrout breake at once,
To priſon eyes, nere looke on libertie.
Vile earth to earth reſigne, end motion here,
And thou and Romeo preſſe on heauie beere.

speech.speaker: Nur.
speech.line: O Tybalt, Tybalt, the beſt Friend I had:
O curteous Tybalt honeſt Gentleman,
That euer I ſhould liue to ſee thee dead.

speech.speaker: Iul.
speech.line: What ſtorme is this that blowes ſo contrarie?
Is Romeo ſlaughtred? and is Tybalt dead?
My deareſt Cozen, and my dearer Lord:
Then dreadfull Trumpet ſound the generall doome,
For who is liuing, if thoſe two are gone?

speech.speaker: Nur.
speech.line: Tybalt is gone, and Romeo baniſhed,
Romeo that kil’d him, he is baniſhed.

speech.speaker: Iul.
speech.line: O God!
Did Romeo's hand ſhed Tybalts blood
It did, it did, alas the day, it did.

speech.speaker: Nur.
speech.line: O Serpent heart, hid with a flowring face.

speech.speaker: Iul.
speech.line: Did euer Dragon keepe ſo faire a Caue?
Beautifull Tyrant, fiend Angelicall:
Rauenous Doue-feather’d Rauen,
Woluiſh-rauening Lambe,
Diſpiſed ſubſtance of Diuineſt ſhow:
Iuſt oppoſite to what thou iuſtly ſeem’ſt,
A dimne Saint, an Honourable Villaine:
O Nature! what had’ſt thou to doe in hell,
When thou did’ſt bower the ſpirit of a fiend
In mortall paradiſe of ſuch ſweet fleſh?
Was euer booke containing ſuch vile matter
So fairely bound? O that deceit ſhould dwell
In ſuch a gorgeous Pallace.

speech.speaker: Nur.
speech.line: There’s no truſt, no faith, no honeſtie in men,
All periur’d, all forſworne, all naught, all diſſemblers,
Ah where’s my man? giue me ſome Aqua-vitæ?
Theſe griefes, theſe woes, theſe ſorrowes make me old:
Shame come to Romeo.

speech.speaker: Iul.
speech.line: Bliſter’d be thy tongue
For ſuch a wiſh, he was not borne to ſhame:
Vpon his brow ſhame is aſham’d to ſit;
For ‘tis a throane where Honour may be Crown’d
Sole Monarch of the vniuerſall earth:
O what a beaſt was I to chide him?

speech.speaker: Nur.
speech.line: Will you ſpeake well of him,
That kil’d your Cozen?

speech.speaker: Iul.
speech.line: Shall I ſpeake ill of him that is my husband?
Ah poore my Lord, what tongue ſhall ſmooth thy name,
When I thy three houres wife haue mangled it.
But wherefore Villaine did’ſt thou kill my Cozin?
That Villaine Cozin would haue kil’d my husband:
Backe fooliſh teares, backe to your natiue ſpring,
Your tributarie drops belong to woe,
Which you miſtaking offer vp to ioy:
My husband liues that Tibalt would haue ſlaine,
And Tibalt dead that would haue ſlaine my husband:
All this is comfort, wherefore weepe I then?
Some words there was worſer then Tybalts death
That murdered me, I would forget it feine,
But oh, it preſſes to my memory,
Like damned guilty deedes to ſinners minds,
Tybalt is dead and Romeo baniſhed:
That baniſhed, that one word baniſhed,
Hath ſlaine ten thouſand Tibalts: Tibalts death
Was woe inough if it had ended there:
Or if ſower woe delights in fellowſhip,
And needly will be rankt with other griefes,
Why followed not when ſhe ſaid Tibalts dead,
Thy Father or thy Mother, nay or both,
Which moderne lamentation might haue mou’d.
But which a rere-ward following Tybalts death
Romeo is baniſhed to ſpeake that word,
Is Father, Mother, Tybalt, Romeo, Iuliet,
All ſlaine, all dead: Romeo is baniſhed,
There is no end, no limit, meaſure, bound,
In that words death, no words can that woe ſound.
Where is my Father and my Mother Nurſe?

speech.speaker: Nur.
speech.line: Weeping and wailing ouer Tybalts Coarſe,
Will you go to them? I will bring you thither.

speech.speaker: Iu.
speech.line: Waſh they his wounds with tears: mine ſhal be ſpent
When theirs are drie for Romeo's baniſhment.
Take vp thoſe Cordes, poore ropes you are beguil’d,
Both you and I for Romeo is exild:
He made you for a high-way to my bed,
But I a Maid, die Maiden widowed.
Come Cord, come Nurſe, Ile to my wedding bed,
And death not Romeo, take my Maiden head.

speech.speaker: Nur.
speech.line: Hie to your Chamber, Ile find Romeo
To comfort you, I wot well where he is:
Harke ye your Romeo will be heere at night,
Ile to him, he is hid at Lawrence Cell.

speech.speaker: Iul.
speech.line: O find him, giue this Ring to my true Knight,
And bid him come, to take his laſt farewell.

speech.speaker: Fri.
speech.line: Romeo come forth,
Come forth thou fearfull man,
Affliƈtion is enamor’d of thy parts
And thou art wedded to calamitie.

speech.speaker: Rom.
speech.line: Father what newes?
What is the Princes Doome?
What ſorrow craues acquaintance at my hand,
That I yet know not?

speech.speaker: Fri.
speech.line: Too familiar
Is my deare Sonne with ſuch ſowre Company:
I bring thee tydings of the Princes Doome.

speech.speaker: Rom.
speech.line: What leſſe then Doomeſday,
Is the Princes Doome?

speech.speaker: Fri.
speech.line: A gentler iudgement vaniſht from his lips,
Not bodies death, but bodies baniſhment.

speech.speaker: Rom.
speech.line: Ha, baniſhment? be mercifull, ſay death:
For exile hath more terror in his looke,
Much more then death: do not ſay baniſhment.

speech.speaker: Fri.
speech.line: Here from Verona art thou baniſhed:
Be patient, for the world is broad and wide.

speech.speaker: Rom.
speech.line: There is no world without Verona walles,
But Purgatorie, Torture, hell it ſelfe:
Hence baniſhed, is baniſht from the world,
And worlds exile is death. Then baniſhed,
Is death, miſtearm’d, calling death baniſhed,
Thou cut’ſt my head off with a golden Axe,
And ſmileſt vpon the ſtroke that murders me.

speech.speaker: Fri.
speech.line: O deadly ſin, O rude vnthankefulneſſe!
Thy falt our Law calles death, but the kind Prince
Taking thy part, hath ruſht aſide the Law,
And turn’d that blacke word death, to baniſhment.
This is deare mercy, and thou ſeeſt it not.

speech.speaker: Rom.
speech.line: ‘Tis Torture and not mercy, heauen is here
Where Iuliet liues, and euery Cat and Dog,
And little Mouſe, euery vnworthy thing
Liue here in Heauen and may looke on her,
But Romeo may not. More Validitie,
More Honourable ſtate, more Courtſhip liues
In carrion Flies, then Romeo: they may ſeaze
On the white wonder of deare Iuliets hand,
And ſteale immortall bleſſing from her lips,
Who euen in pure and veſtall modeſtie
Still bluſh, as thinking their owne kiſſes ſin.
This may Flies doe, when I from this muſt flie,
And ſaiſt thou yet, that exile is not death?
But Romeo may not, hee is baniſhed.
Had’ſt thou no poyſon mixt, no ſharpe ground knife,
No ſudden meane of death, though nere ſo meane,
But baniſhed to kill me? Baniſhed?
O Frier, the damned vſe that word in hell:
Howlings attends it, how haſt then the hart
Being a Diuine, a Ghoſtly Confeſſor,
A Sin-Abſoluer, and my Friend profeſt:
To mangle me with that word, baniſhed?

speech.speaker: Fri.
speech.line: Then fond Mad man, heare me ſpeake.

speech.speaker: Rom.
speech.line: O thou wilt ſpeake againe of baniſhment.

speech.speaker: Fri.
speech.line: Ile giue thee Armour to keepe off that word,
Aduerſities ſweete milke, Philoſophie,
To comfort thee, though thou art baniſhed.

speech.speaker: Rom.
speech.line: Yet baniſhed? hang vp Philoſophie:
Vnleſſe Philoſophie can make a Iuliet,
Diſplant a Towne, reuerſe a Princes Doome,
It helpes not, it preuailes not, talke no more.

speech.speaker: Fri.
speech.line: O then I ſee, that Mad men haue no eares.

speech.speaker: Rom.
speech.line: How ſhould they,
When wiſemen haue no eyes?

speech.speaker: Fri.
speech.line: Let me diſpaire with thee of thy eſtate.

speech.speaker: Rom.
speech.line: Thou can’ſt not ſpeake of that ӳ doſt not feele,
Wert thou as young as Iuliet my Loue:
An houre but married, Tybalt murdered,
Doting like me, and like me baniſhed,
Then mighteſt thou ſpeake,
Then mighteſt thou teare thy hayre,
And fall vpon the ground as I doe now,
Taking the meaſure of an vnmade graue.

speech.speaker: Frier.
speech.line: Ariſe one knockes,
Good Romeo hide thy ſelfe.

speech.speaker: Rom.
speech.line: Not I,
Vnleſſe the breath of Hartſicke groanes
Miſt-like infold me from the ſearch of eyes.

speech.speaker: Fri.
speech.line: Harke how they knocke:
(Who’s there) Romeo ariſe,
Thou wilt be taken, ſtay a while, ſtand vp:
Run to my ſtudy: by and by, Gods will
What ſimpleneſſe is this: I come, I come.
Who knocks ſo hard?
Whence come you? what’s your will?

speech.speaker: Nur.
speech.line: Let me come in,
And you ſhall know my errand:
I come from Lady Iuliet.

speech.speaker: Fri.
speech.line: Welcome then.

speech.speaker: Nur.
speech.line: O holy Frier, O tell me holy Frier,
Where's my Ladies Lord? where's Romeo?

speech.speaker: Fri.
speech.line: There on the ground,
With his owne teares made drunke.

speech.speaker: Nur.
speech.line: O he is euen in my Miſtreſſe caſe,
Iuſt in her caſe. O wofull ſimpathy:
Pittious predicament, euen ſo lies ſhe,
Blubbring and weeping weeping and blubbring,
Stand vp, ſtand vp, ſtand and you be a man,
For Iuliets ſake, for her ſake rise and ſtand:
Why ſhould you fall into ſo deepe an O.

speech.speaker: Rom.
speech.line: Nurſe.

speech.speaker: Nur.
speech.line: Ah ſir, ah ſir, deaths the end of all.

speech.speaker: Rom.
speech.line: Speak’ſt thou of Iuliet? how is it with her?
Doth not ſhe thinke me an old Murtherer,
Now I haue ſtain’d the Childhood of our ioy,
With blood remoued, but little from her owne?
Where is ſhe? and how doth ſhe? and what ſayes
My conceal’d Lady to our conceal’d Loue?

speech.speaker: Nur.
speech.line: Oh ſhe ſayes nothing ſir, but weeps and weeps,
And now fals on her bed, and then ſtarts vp,
And Tybalt calls, and then on Romeo cries,
And then downe falls againe.

speech.speaker: Ro.
speech.line: As if that name ſhot from the dead leuell of a Gun,
Did murder her, as that names curſed hand
Murdred her kinſman. Oh tell me Frier, tell me,
In what vile part of this Anatomie
Doth my name lodge? Tell me, that I may ſacke
The hatefull Manſion.

speech.speaker: Fri.
speech.line: Hold thy deſperate hand:
Art thou a man? thy forme cries out thou art:
Thy teares are womaniſh, thy wild aƈts denote
The vnreaſonable Furie of a beaſt.
Vnſeemely woman, in a ſeeming man,
And ill beſeeming beaſt in ſeeming both,
Thou haſt amaz’d me. By my holy order,
I thought thy diſpoſition better temper’d.
Haſt thou ſlaine Tybalt? wilt thou ſlay thy ſelfe?
And ſlay thy Lady, that in thy life lies,
By doing damned hate vpon thy ſelfe?
Why rayl’ſt thou on thy birth? the heauen and earth?
Since birth, and heauen and earth, all three do meete
In thee at once, which thou at once would’ſt looſe.
Fie, fie, thou ſham’ſt thy ſhape, thy loue, thy wit,
Which like a Vſurer abound’ſt in all:
And vſeſt none in that true vſe indeed,
Which ſhould bedecke thy ſhape, thy loue, thy wit:
Thy Noble ſhape, is but a forme of waxe,
Digreſſing from the Valour of a man,
Thy deare Loue ſworne but hollow periurie,
Killing that Loue which thou haſt vow’d to cheriſh.
Thy wit, that Ornament, to ſhape and Loue,
Miſhapen in the conduƈt of them both:
Like powder in a skilleſſe Souldiers flaske,
Is ſet a fire by thine owne ignorance,
And thou diſmembred with thine owne defence.
What, rowſe thee man, thy Iuliet is aliue,
For whoſe deare ſake thou waſt but lately dead.
There art thou happy. Tybalt would kill thee,
But thou ſlew’ſt Tybalt, there art thou happie.
The law that threatned death became thy Friend.
And turn’d it to exile, there art thou happy.
A packe or bleſſing light vpon thy backe,
Happineſſe Courts thee in her beſt array,
But like a miſhaped and ſullen wench,
Thou putteſt vp thy Fortune and thy Loue:
Take heed, take heed, for ſuch die miſerable.
Goe get thee to thy Loue as was decreed,
Aſcend her Chamber, hence and comfort her:
But looke thou ſtay not till the watch be ſet,
For then thou canſt not paſſe to Mantua,
Where thou ſhalt liue till we can finde a time
To blaze your marriage, reconcile your Friends,
Beg pardon of thy Prince, and call thee backe,
With twenty hundred thouſand times more ioy
Then thou went’ſt forth in lamentation.
Goe before Nurſe, commend me to thy Lady,
And bid her haſten all the houſe to bed,
Which heauy ſorrow makes them apt vnto.
Romeo is comming.

speech.speaker: Nur.
speech.line: O Lord, I could haue ſtaid here all night,
To heare good counſell: oh what learning is!
My Lord Ile tell my Lady you will come.

speech.speaker: Rom.
speech.line: Do ſo, and bid my Sweete prepare to chide.

speech.speaker: Nur.
speech.line: Heere ſir, a Ring ſhe bid me giue you ſir:
Hie you, make haſt, for it growes very late.

speech.speaker: Rom.
speech.line: How well my comfort is reuiu’d by this.

speech.speaker: Fri.
speech.line: Go hence,
Goodnight, and here ſtands all your ſtate:
Either be gone before the watch be ſet,
Or by the breake of day diſguis’d from hence,
Soiourne in Mantua, Ile find out your man,
And he ſhall ſignifie from time to time,
Euery good hap to you, that chaunces heere:
Giue me thy hand, ‘tis late, farewell, goodnight.

speech.speaker: Rom.
speech.line: But that a ioy paſt ioy, calls out on me,
It were a griefe, ſo briefe to part with thee:
Farewell.

scene.stagedir: Enter old Capulet, his Wife and Paris.

speech.speaker: Cap.
speech.line: Things haue falne out ſir ſo vnluckily,
That we haue had no time to moue our Daughter:
Looke you, ſhe Lou’d her kinſman Tybalt dearely,
And ſo did I. Well, we were borne to die.
‘Tis very late, ſhe’l not come downe to night:
I promiſe you, but for your company,
I would haue bin a bed an houre ago.

speech.speaker: Par.
speech.line: Theſe times of wo, affoord no times to wooe:
Madam goodnight, commend me to your Daughter.

speech.speaker: Lady.
speech.line: I will, and know her mind early to morrow,
To night, ſhe is mewed vp to her heauineſſe.

speech.speaker: Cap.
speech.line: Sir Paris, I will make a deſperate tender
Of my Childes loue: I thinke ſhe will be rul’d
In all respeƈts by me: nay more, I doubt it not.
Wife, go you to her ere you go to bed,
Acquaint her here, of my Sonne Paris Loue,
And bid her, marke you me, on Wendſday next,
But ſoft, what day is this?

speech.speaker: Par.
speech.line: Monday my Lord.

speech.speaker: Cap.
speech.line: Monday, ha ha: well Wendſday is too ſoone,
A Thurſday let it be: a Thurſday tell her,
She ſhall be married to this Noble Earle:
Will you be ready? do you like this haſt?
Weele keepe no great adoe, a Friend or two,
For harke you, Tybalt being ſlaine ſo late,
It may be thought we held him careleſly,
Being our kinſman, if we reuell much:
Therefore weele haue ſome halfe a dozen Friends,
And there an end. But what ſay you to Thurſday?

speech.speaker: Paris.
speech.line: My Lord,
I would that Thurſday were to morrow.

speech.speaker: Cap.
speech.line: Well, get you gone, a Thurſday, be it then:
Go you to Iuliet ere you go to bed,
Prepare her wife, againſt this wedding day.
Farewell my Lord, light to my Chamber hoa,
Afore me, it is ſo late, that we may call it early by and by,
Goodnight.

speech.speaker: Iul.
speech.line: Wilt thou be gone? It is not yet neere day:
It was the Nightingale, and not the Larke,
That pier’ſt the fearefull hollow of thine eare,
Nightly ſhe ſings on yond Pomgranet tree,
Beleeue me Loue, it was the Nightingale.

speech.speaker: Rom.
speech.line: It was the Larke the Herauld of the Morne:
No Nightingale: looke Loue what enuious ſtreakes
Do lace the ſeuering Cloudes in yonder Eaſt:
Nights Candles are burnt out, and Iocond day
Stands tipto on the miſtie Mountaines tops,
I muſt be gone and liue, or ſtay and die.

speech.speaker: Iul.
speech.line: Yond light is not daylight, I know it I:
It is ſome Meteor that the Sun exhales,
To be to thee this night a Torch-bearer,
And light thee on thy way to Mantua.
Therefore ſtay yet, thou need’ſt not be gone.

speech.speaker: Rom.
speech.line: Let me be tane, let me be put to death,
I am content, ſo thou wilt haue it ſo.
Ile ſay yon gray is not the mornings eye,
‘Tis but the pale reflexe of Cinthias brow.
Nor that is not Larke whoſe noates do beate
The vaulty heauen ſo high aboue our heads,
I haue more care to ſtay, then will to go:
Come death and welcome, Iuliet wills it ſo.
How iſt my ſoule, lets talke, it is not day.

speech.speaker: Iuli.
speech.line: It is, it is, hie hence be gone away:
It is the Larke that ſings ſo out of tune,
Straining harſh Diſcords, and vnpleaſing Sharpes.
Some ſay the Larke makes ſweete Diuiſion;
This doth not ſo: for ſhe diuideth vs.
Some ſay, the Larke and loathed Toad change eyes,
O now I would they had chang’d voyces too:
Since arme from arme that voyce doth vs affray,
Hunting thee hence, with Huntſ-vp to the day,
O now be gone, more light and it light growes.

speech.speaker: Rom.
speech.line: More light & light, more darke & darke our woes.

speech.speaker: Nur.
speech.line: Madam.

speech.speaker: Iul.
speech.line: Nurſe.

speech.speaker: Nur.
speech.line: Your Lady Mother is comming to your chamber,
The day is broke, be wary, looke about.

speech.speaker: Iul.
speech.line: Then window let day in, and let life out.

speech.speaker: Rom.
speech.line: Farewell, farewell, one kiſſe and Ile deſcend.

speech.speaker: Iul.
speech.line: Art thou gone ſo? Loue, Lord, ay Husband, Friend,
I muſt heare from thee euery day in the houre,
For in a minute there are many dayes,
O by this count I ſhall be much in yeares,
Ere I againe behold my Romeo.

speech.speaker: Rom.
speech.line: Farewell:
I will omit no oportunitie,
That may conuey my greetings Loue, to thee.

speech.speaker: Iul.
speech.line: O thinkeſt thou we ſhall euer meet againe?

speech.speaker: Rom.
speech.line: I doubt it not, and all theſe woes ſhall ſerue
For ſweet diſcourſes in our time to come.

speech.speaker: Iuliet.
speech.line: O God! I haue an ill Diuining ſoule,
Me thinkes I ſee thee now, thou art ſo lowe,
As one dead in the bottome of a Tombe,
Either my eye-ſight failes, or thou look’ſt pale.

speech.speaker: Rom.
speech.line: And truſt me Loue, in my eye ſo do you:
Drie ſorrow drinkes our blood. Adue, adue.

speech.speaker: Iul.
speech.line: O Fortune, Fortune, all men call thee fickle,
If thou art fickle, what doſt thou with him
That is renown’d for faith? be fickle Fortune:
For then I hope thou wilt not keepe him long,
But ſend him backe.

speech.speaker: Lad.
speech.line: Ho Daughter, are you vp?

speech.speaker: Iul.
speech.line: Who iſt that calls? Is it my Lady Mother.
Is ſhe not downe ſo late, or vp ſo early?
What vnaccuſtom’d cauſe procures her hither?

speech.speaker: Lad.
speech.line: Why how now Iuliet?

speech.speaker: Iul.
speech.line: Madam I am not well.

speech.speaker: Lad.
speech.line: Euermore weeping for your Cozins death?
What wilt thou waſh him from his graue with teares?
And if thou could’ſt, thou could’ſt not make him liue:
Therefore haue done, ſome griefe ſhewes much of Loue,
But much of griefe, ſhewes ſtill ſome want of wit.

speech.speaker: Iul.
speech.line: Yet let me weepe, for ſuch a feeling loſſe.

speech.speaker: Lad.
speech.line: So ſhall you feele the loſſe, but not the Friend
Which you weepe for.

speech.speaker: Iul.
speech.line: Feeling ſo the loſſe,
I cannot chuſe but euer weepe the Friend.

speech.speaker: La.
speech.line: Well Girle, thou weep’ſt not ſo much for his death,
As that the Villaine liues which ſlaughter’d him.

speech.speaker: Iul.
speech.line: What Villaine, Madam?

speech.speaker: Lad.
speech.line: That ſame Villaine Romeo.

speech.speaker: Iul.
speech.line: Villaine and he, be many miles aſſunder:
God pardon, I doe with all my heart:
And yet no man like he, doth grieue my heart.

speech.speaker: Lad.
speech.line: That is becauſe the Traitor liues.

speech.speaker: Iul.
speech.line: I Madam from the reach of theſe my hands:
Would none but I might venge my Cozins death.

speech.speaker: Lad.
speech.line: We will haue vengeance for it, feare thou not.
Then weepe no more, Ile ſend to one in Mantua,
Where that ſame baniſht Run-agate doth liue,
Shall giue him ſuch an vnaccustom’d dram,
That he ſhall ſoone keepe Tybalt company:
And then I hope thou wilt be ſatisfied.

speech.speaker: Iul.
speech.line: Indeed I neuer ſhall be ſatisfied
With Romeo, till I behold him. Dead
Is my poore heart ſo for a kinſman vext:
Madam if you could find out but a man
To beare a poyſon, I would temper it;
That Romeo ſhould vpon receit thereof,
Soone ſleepe in quiet. O how my heart abhors
To heare him nam’d, and cannot come to him,
To wreake the Loue I bore my Cozin,
Vpon his body that hath ſlaughter’d him.

speech.speaker: Mo.
speech.line: Find thou the meanes, and Ile find ſuch a man.
But now Ile tell thee ioyfull tidings Gyrle.

speech.speaker: Iul.
speech.line: And ioy comes well, in ſuch a needy time,
What are they, beſeech your Ladyſhip?

speech.speaker: Mo.
speech.line: Well, well, thou haſt a carefull Father Child?
One who to put thee from thy heauineſſe,
Hath ſorted out a ſudden day of ioy,
That thou expeƈts not, nor I lookt not for.

speech.speaker: Iul.
speech.line: Madam in happy time, what day is this?

speech.speaker: Mo.
speech.line: Marry my Child, early next Thurſday morne,
The gallant, young, and Noble Gentleman,
The Countie Paris at Saint Peters Church,
Shall happily make thee a ioyfull Bride.

speech.speaker: Iul.
speech.line: Now by Saint Peters Church, and Peter too,
He ſhall not make me there a ioyfull Bride.
I wonder at this haſt, that I muſt wed
Ere he that ſhould be Husband comes to woe:
I pray you tell my Lord and Father Madam,
I will not marrie yet, and when I doe, I ſweare
It ſhallbe Romeo, whom you know I hate
Rather then Paris. Theſe are newes indeed.

speech.speaker: Mo.
speech.line: Here comes your Father, tell him ſo your ſelfe,
And ſee how he will take it at your hands.

speech.speaker: Cap.
speech.line: When the Sun ſets, the earth doth drizzle daew
But for the Sunſet of my Brothers Sonne,
It raines downright.
How now? A Conduit Gyrle, what ſtill in teares?
Euermore ſhowring in one little body?
Thou counterfaits a Barke, a Sea, a Wind:
For ſtill thy eyes, which I may call the Sea,
Do ebbe and flow with teares, the Barke thy body is
Sayling in this ſalt floud, the windes thy ſighes,
Who raging with the teares and they with them,
Without a ſudden calme will ouer ſet
Thy tempeſt toſſed body. How now wife?
Haue you deliuered to her our decree?

speech.speaker: Lady.
speech.line: I ſir;
But ſhe will none, ſhe giues you thankes,
I would the foole were married to her graue.

speech.speaker: Cap.
speech.line: Soft, take me with you, take me with you wife,
How, will ſhe none? doth ſhe not giue vs thanks?
Is ſhe not proud? doth ſhe not count her bleſt,
Vnworthy as ſhe is, that we haue wrought
So worthy a Gentleman, to be her Bridegroome

speech.speaker: Iul.
speech.line: Not proud you haue,
But thankfull that you haue:
Proud can I neuer be of what I haue,
But thankfull euen for hate, that is meant Loue.

speech.speaker: Cap.
speech.line: How now?
How now? Chopt Logicke? what is this?
Proud, and I thanke you: and I thanke you not.
Thanke me no thankings, nor proud me no prouds,
But fettle your fine ioints ‘gainſt Thurſday next,
To go with Paris to Saint Peters Church:
Or I will drag thee, on a Hurdle thither.
Out you greene ſickneſſe carrion, out you baggage,
You tallow face.

speech.speaker: Lady.
speech.line: Fie, fie, what are you mad?

speech.speaker: Iul.
speech.line: Good Father, I beſeech you on my knees
Heare me with patience, but to ſpeake a word.

speech.speaker: Fa.
speech.line: Hang thee young baggage, diſobedient wretch,
I tell thee what, get thee to Church a Thurſday,
Or neuer after looke me in the face.
Speake not, reply not, do not anſwere me.
My fingers itch, wife: we ſcarce thought vs bleſt,
That God had lent vs but this onely Child,
But now I ſee this one is one too much,
And that we haue a curſe in hauing her:
Out on her Hilding.

speech.speaker: Nur.
speech.line: God in heauen bleſſe her,
You are too blame my Lord to rate her ſo.

speech.speaker: Fa.
speech.line: And why my Lady wiſedome? hold your tongue,
Good Prudence, ſmatter with your goſſip, go.

speech.speaker: Nur.
speech.line: I ſpeake no treaſon,
Father, O Godigoden,
May not one ſpeake?

speech.speaker: Fa.
speech.line: Peace you mumbling foole,
Vtter your grauitie ore a Goſſips bowles
For here we need it not.

speech.speaker: La.
speech.line: You are too hot.

speech.speaker: Fa.
speech.line: Gods bread, it makes me mad:
Day, night, houre, ride, time, worke, play,
Alone in companie, ſtill my care hath bin
To haue her matcht, and hauing now prouided
A Gentleman of Noble Parentage,
Of faire Demeanes, Youthfull, and Nobly Allied,
Stuft as they ſay with Honourable parts,
Proportion’d as ones thought would wiſh a man,
And then to haue a wretched puling foole,
A whining mammet, in her Fortunes tender,
To anſwer, Ile not wed, I cannot Loue:
I am too young, I pray you pardon me.
But, and you will not wed, Ile pardon you.
Graze where you will, you ſhall not houſe with me:
Looke too’t, thinke on’t, I do not vſe to ieſt.
Thurſday is neere, lay hand on heart, aduiſe,
And you be mine, Ile giue you to my Friend:
And you be not, hang, beg, ſtarue, die in the ſtreets,
For by my ſoule, Ile nere acknowledge thee,
Nor what is mine ſhall neuer do thee good:
Truſt too’t, bethinke you, Ile not be forſworne

speech.speaker: Iuli.
speech.line: Is there no pittie ſitting in the Cloudes,
That ſees into the bottome of my griefe?
O ſweet my Mother caſt me not away,
Delay this marriage, for a month, a weeke,
Or if you do not, make the Bridall bed
In that dim Monument where Tybalt lies.

speech.speaker: Mo.
speech.line: Talke not to me, for Ile not ſpeake a word,
Do as thou wilt, for I haue done with thee.

speech.speaker: Iul.
speech.line: O God!
O Nurſe, how ſhall this be preuented?
My Husband is on earth, my faith in heauen,
How ſhall that faith returne againe to earth,
Vnleſſe that Husband ſend it me from heauen,
By leauing earth? Comfort me, counſaile me:
Alacke, alacke, that heauen ſhould praƈtiſe ſtratagems
Vpon ſo ſoft a ſubieƈt as my ſelfe.
What ſaiſt thou? haſt thou not a word of ioy?
Some comfort Nurſe.

speech.speaker: Nur.
speech.line: Faith here it is,
Romeo is baniſhed, and all the world to nothing,
That he dares nere come backe to challenge you:
Or if he do, it needs muſt be by ſtealth.
Then ſince the caſe ſo ſtands as now it doth,
I thinke it beſt you married with the Countie,
O hee’s a Louely Gentleman:
Romeos a diſh-clout to him: an Eagle Madam
Hath not ſo greene, ſo quicke, ſo faire an eye
As Paris hath, beſhrow my very heart,
I thinke you are happy in this ſecond match,
For it excels your firſt: or if it did not,
Your firſt is dead, or ‘twere as good he were,
As liuing here and you no vſe of him.

speech.speaker: Iul.
speech.line: Speakeſt thou from thy heart?

speech.speaker: Nur.
speech.line: And from my ſoule too,
Or elſe beſhrew them both.

speech.speaker: Iul.
speech.line: Amen.

speech.speaker: Nur.
speech.line: What?

speech.speaker: Iul.
speech.line: Well, thou haſt comforted me marue’lous much,
Go in, and tell my Lady I am gone,
Hauing diſpleaſ’d my Father, to Lawrence Cell,
To make confeſſion, and to be abſolu’d.

speech.speaker: Nur.
speech.line: Marrie I will, and this is wiſely done.

speech.speaker: Iul.
speech.line: Auncient damnation, O moſt wicked fiend!
It is more ſin to wiſh me thus forſworne,
Or to diſpraiſe my Lord with that ſame tongue
Which ſhe hath praiſ’d him with aboue compare,
So many thouſand times? Go Counſellor,
Thou and my boſome henceforth ſhall be twaine:
Ile to the Frier to know his remedie,
If all elſe faile, my ſelfe haue power to die.

speech.speaker: Fri.
speech.line: On Thurſday ſir? the time is very ſhort.

speech.speaker: Par.
speech.line: My Father Capulet will haue it ſo,
And I am nothing ſlow to ſlack his haſt.

speech.speaker: Fri.
speech.line: You ſay you do not know the Ladies mind?
Vneuen is the courſe, I like it not.

speech.speaker: Pa.
speech.line: Immoderately ſhe weepes for Tybalts death,
And therfore haue I little talke of Loue,
For Venus ſmiles not in a houſe of teares.
Now ſir, her Father counts it dangerous
That ſhe doth giue her ſorrow ſo much ſway:
And in his wiſedome, haſts our marriage,
To ſtop the inundation of her teares,
Which too much minded by her ſelfe alone,
May be put from her by ſocietie.
Now doe you know the reaſon of this haſt?

speech.speaker: Fri.
speech.line: I would I knew not why it ſhould be ſlow’d.
Looke ſir, here comes the Lady towards my Cell.

speech.speaker: Par.
speech.line: Happily met, my Lady and my wife.

speech.speaker: Iul.
speech.line: That may be ſir, when I may be a wife.

speech.speaker: Par.
speech.line: That may be, muſt be Loue, on Thurſday next.

speech.speaker: Iul.
speech.line: What muſt be ſhall be.

speech.speaker: Fri.
speech.line: That's a certaine text.

speech.speaker: Par.
speech.line: Come you to make confeſſion to this Father?

speech.speaker: Iul.
speech.line: To anſwere that, I ſhould confeſſe to you.

speech.speaker: Par.
speech.line: Do not denie to him, that you Loue me.

speech.speaker: Iul.
speech.line: I will confeſſe to you that I Loue him.

speech.speaker: Par.
speech.line: So will ye, I am ſure that you Loue me.

speech.speaker: Iul.
speech.line: If I do ſo, it will be of more price,
Being ſpoke behind your backe, then to your face.

speech.speaker: Par.
speech.line: Poore ſoule, thy face is much abuſ’d with teares.

speech.speaker: Iul.
speech.line: The teares haue got ſmall viƈtorie by that:
For it was bad inough before their ſpight.

speech.speaker: Pa.
speech.line: Thou wrong’ſt it more then teares with that report.

speech.speaker: Iul.
speech.line: That is no ſlaunder ſir, which is a truth,
And what I ſpake, I ſpake it to thy face.

speech.speaker: Par.
speech.line: Thy face is mine, and thou haſt ſlaundred it.

speech.speaker: Iul.
speech.line: It may be ſo, for it is not mine owne.
Are you at leiſure, Holy Father now,
Or ſhall I come to you at euening Maſſe?

speech.speaker: Fri.
speech.line: My leiſure ſerues me penſiue daughter now.
My Lord you muſt intreat the time alone.

speech.speaker: Par.
speech.line: Godſheild: I ſhould diſturbe Deuotion,
Iuliet, on Thurſday early will I rowſe yee,
Till then adue, and keepe this holy kiſſe.

speech.speaker: Iul.
speech.line: O ſhut the doore, and when thou haſt done ſo,
Come weepe with me, paſt hope, paſt care, paſt helpe.

speech.speaker: Fri.
speech.line: O Iuliet, I alreadie know thy griefe,
It ſtreames me paſt the compaſſe of my wits:
I heare thou muſt and nothing may prorogue it,
On Thurſday next be married to this Countie.

speech.speaker: Iul.
speech.line: Tell me not Frier that thou heareſt of this,
Vnleſſe thou tell me how I may preuent it:
If in thy wiſedome, thou canſt giue no helpe,
Do thou but call my reſolution wiſe,
And with this knife, Ile helpe it preſently.
God ioyn’d my heart, and Romeos, thou our hands,
And ere this hand by thee to Romeo ſeal’d:
Shall be the Labell to another Deede,
Or my true heart with trecherous reuolt,
Turne to another, this ſhall ſlay them both:
Therefore out of thy long experien’ſt time,
Giue me ſome preſent counſell, or behold
Twixt my extreames and me, this bloody knife
Shall play the vmpeere, arbitrating that,
Which the commiſſion of thy yeares and art,
Could to no iſſue of true honour bring:
Be not ſo long to ſpeak, I long to die,
If what thou ſpeak’ſt, ſpeake not of remedy.

speech.speaker: Fri.
speech.line: Hold Daughter, I doe ſpie a kind of hope,
Which craues as deſperate an execution,
As that is deſperate which we would preuent.
If rather then to marrie Countie Paris
Thou haſt the ſtrength of will to ſlay thy ſelfe,
Then is it likely thou wilt vndertake
A thinglike death to chide away this ſhame,
That coap’ſt with death himſelfe, to ſcape fro it:
And if thou dar’ſt, Ile giue thee remedie.

speech.speaker: Iul.
speech.line: Oh bid me leape, rather then marrie Paris,
From of the Battlements of any Tower,
Or walke in theeuiſh waies, or bid me lurke
Where Serpents are: chaine me with roaring Beares
Or hide me nightly in a Charnell houſe,
Orecouered quite with dead mens ratling bones,
With reckie ſhankes and yellow chappels ſculls:
Or bid me go into a new made graue,
And hide me with a dead man in his graue,
Things that to heare them told, haue made me tremble,
And I will doe it without feare or doubt,
To liue an vnſtained wife to my ſweet Loue.

speech.speaker: Fri.
speech.line: Hold then: goe home, be merrie, giue conſent,
To marrie Paris: wenſday is to morrow,
To morrow night looke that thou lie alone,
Let not thy Nurſe lie with thee in thy Chamber:
Take thou this Violl being then in bed,
And this diſtilling liquor drinke thou off,
When preſently through all thy veines ſhall run,
A cold and drowſie humour: for no pulſe
Shall keepe his natiue progreſſe, but ſurcease:
No warmth, no breath ſhall teſtifie thou liueſt,
The Roſes in thy lips and cheekes ſhall fade
To many aſhes, the eyes windowes fall
Like death when he ſhut vp the day of life:
Each part depriu’d of ſupple gouernment,
Shall ſtiffe and ſtarke, and cold appeare like death,
And in this borrowed likeneſſe of ſhrunke death
Thou ſhalt continue two and forty houres,
And then awake, as from a pleaſant ſleepe.
Now when the Bridegroome in the morning comes,
To rowſe thee from thy bed, there art thou dead:
Then as the manner of our country is,
In thy beſt Robes vncouer’d on the Beere,
Be borne to buriall in thy kindreds graue:
Thou ſhalt be borne to that ſame ancient vault,
Where all the kindred of the Capulets lie,
In the meane time againſt thou ſhalt awake,
Shall Romeo by my Letters know our drift,
And hither ſhall he come, and that very night
Shall Romeo beare thee hence to Mantua.
And this ſhall free thee from this preſent ſhame,
If no inconſtant toy nor womaniſh feare,
Abate thy valour in the aƈting it.

speech.speaker: Iul.
speech.line: Giue me, giue me, O tell not me of care.

speech.speaker: Fri.
speech.line: Hold get you gone, be ſtrong and proſperous:
In this reſolue, Ile ſend a Frier with ſpeed
To Mantua with my Letters to thy Lord.

speech.speaker: Iu.
speech.line: Loue giue me ſtrength,
And ſtrength ſhall helpe afford:
Farewell deare father.

scene.stagedir: Enter Father Capulet, Mother, Nurſe, and Seruing men, two or three.

speech.speaker: Cap.
speech.line: So many gueſts inuite as here are writ,
Sirrah, go hire me twenty cunning Cookes.

speech.speaker: Ser.
speech.line: You ſhall haue none ill ſir, for Ile trie if they can
licke their fingers.

speech.speaker: Cap.
speech.line: How canſt thou trie them ſo?

speech.speaker: Ser.
speech.line: Marrie ſir, ‘tis an ill Cooke that cannot licke his
owne fingers: therefore he that cannot licke his fingers
goes not with me.

speech.speaker: Cap.
speech.line: Go be gone, we ſhall be much vnfurniſht for this
time: what is my Daughter gone to Frier Lawrence?

speech.speaker: Nur.
speech.line: I forſooth.

speech.speaker: Cap.
speech.line: Well he may chance to do ſome good on her,
A peeuiſh ſelfe-wild harlotry it is.

speech.speaker: Nur.
speech.line: See where ſhe comes from ſhrift
With merrie looke.

speech.speaker: Cap.
speech.line: How now my headſtrong,
Where haue you bin gadding?

speech.speaker: Iul.
speech.line: Where I haue learnt me to repent the ſin
Of diſobedient oppoſition:
To you and your beheſts, and am enioyn’d
By holy Lawrence, to fall proſtrate here,
To beg your pardon: pardon I beſeech you,
Henceforward I am euer rul’d by you.

speech.speaker: Cap.
speech.line: Send for the Countie, goe tell him of this,
Ile haue this knot knit vp to morrow morning.

speech.speaker: Iul.
speech.line: I met the youthfull Lord at Lawrence Cell,
And gaue him what becomed Loue I might,
Not ſtepping ore the bounds of modeſtie.

speech.speaker: Cap.
speech.line: Why I am glad on’t, this is well, ſtand vp,
This is as’t ſhould be, let me ſee the County:
I marrie go I ſay, and fetch him hither.
Now afore God, this reueren’d holy Frier,
All our whole Cittie is much bound to him.

speech.speaker: Iul.
speech.line: Nurſe will you goe with me into my Cloſet,
To helpe me ſort ſuch needfull ornaments,
As you thinke fit to furniſh me to morrow?

speech.speaker: Mo.
speech.line: No not till Thurſday, there's time inough.

speech.speaker: Fa.
speech.line: Go Nurſe, go with her,
Weele to Church to morrow.

speech.speaker: Mo.
speech.line: We ſhall be ſhort in our prouiſion,
‘Tis now neere night.

speech.speaker: Fa.
speech.line: Tuſh, I will ſtirre about,
And all things ſhall be well, I warrant thee wife:
Go thou to Iuliet, helpe to deckevp her,
Ile not to bed to night, let me alone:
Ile play the huſwife for this once. What ho?
They are all forth, well I will walke my ſelfe
To Countie Paris, to prepare him vp
Againſt to morrow, my heart is wondrous light,
Since this ſame way-ward Gyrle is ſo reclaim’d.

speech.speaker: Iul.
speech.line: I thoſe attires are beſt, but gentle Nurſe
I pray thee leaue me to my ſelfe to night:
For I haue need of many Oryſons,
To moue the heauens to ſmile vpon my ſtate,
Which well thou know’ſt, is croſſe and full of ſin.

speech.speaker: Mo.
speech.line: What are you buſie ho? need you my help?

speech.speaker: Iul.
speech.line: No Madam, we haue cul’d ſuch neceſſaries
As are behoouefull for our ſtate to morrow:
So pleaſe you, let me now be left alone;
And let the Nurſe this night ſit vp with you,
For I am ſure, you haue your hands full all,
In this ſo ſudden buſineſſe.

speech.speaker: Mo.
speech.line: Goodnight.
Get thee to bed and reſt, for thou haſt need.

speech.speaker: Iul.
speech.line: Farewell:
God knowes when we ſhall meete againe.
I haue a faint cold feare thrills through my veines,
That almoſt freezes vp the heate of fire:
Ile call them backe againe to comfort me.
Nurſe, what ſhould ſhe do here?
My diſmall Sceane, I needs muſt aƈt alone:
Come Viall, what if this mixture do not worke at all?
Shall I be married then to morrow morning?
No, no, this ſhall forbid it. Lie thou there,
What if it be a poyſon which the Frier
Subtilly hath miniſtred to haue me dead,
Leaſt in this marriage he ſhould be diſhonour’d,
Becauſe he married me before to Romeo?
I feare it is, and yet me thinkes it ſhould not,
For he hath ſtill beene tried a holy man.
How, if when I am laid into the Tombe,
I wake before the time that Romeo
Come to redeeme me? There’s a fearefull point:
Shall I not then be ſtifled in the Vault?
To whoſe foule mouth no healthſome ayre breaths in,
And there die ſtrangled ere my Romeo comes.
Or if I liue, is it not very like,
The horrible conceit of death and night,
Together with the terror of the place,
As in a Vaulte, an ancient receptacle,
Where for theſe many hundred yeeres the bones
Of all my buried Aunceſtors are packt,
Where bloody Tybalt, yet but greene in earth,
Lies feſtring in his ſhrow’d, where as they ſay,
At ſome houres in the night, Spirits reſort:
Alacke, alacke, is it not like that I
So early waking, what with loathſome ſmels,
And ſhrikes like Mandrakes torne out of the earth,
That liuing mortalls hearing them, run mad.
O if I walke, ſhall I not be diſtraught,
Inuironed with all theſe hidious feares,
And madly play with my forefathers ioynts?
And plucke the mangled Tybalt from his ſhrow’d?
And in this rage, with ſome great kinſmans bone,
As (with a club) daſh out my deſperate braines.
O looke, me thinks I ſee my Cozins Ghoſt,
Seeking out Romeo that did ſpit his body
Vpon my Rapiers point: ſtay Tybalt, ſtay;
Romeo, Romeo, Romeo, here's drinke: I drinke to thee.

scene.stagedir: Enter Lady of the houſe, and Nurſe.

speech.speaker: Lady.
speech.line: Hold,
Take theſe keies, and fetch more ſpices Nurſe.

speech.speaker: Nur.
speech.line: They call for Dates and Quinces in the Paſtrie.

speech.speaker: Cap.
speech.line: Come, ſtir, ſtir, ſtir,
The ſecond Cocke hath Crow’d,
The Curphew Bell hath rung, ‘tis three a clocke:
Looke to the bakte meates, good Angelica,
Spare not for coſt.

speech.speaker: Nur.
speech.line: Go you Cot-queane, go,
Get you to bed, faith youle be ſicke to morrow
For this nights watching.

speech.speaker: Cap.
speech.line: No not a whit: what? I haue watcht ere now
All night for leſſe cauſe, and nere beene ſicke.

speech.speaker: La.
speech.line: I you haue bin a Mouſe-hunt in your time,
But I will watch you from ſuch watching now.

speech.speaker: Cap.
speech.line: A iealous hood, a iealous hood,
Now fellow, what there?

scene.stagedir: Enter three or foure with ſpits, and logs, and baskets.

speech.speaker: Fel.
speech.line: Things for the Cooke ſir, but I know not what.

speech.speaker: Cap.
speech.line: Make haſt, make haſt, ſirrah, fetch drier Logs.
Call Peter, he will ſhew thee where they are.

speech.speaker: Fel.
speech.line: I haue a head ſir, that will find out logs,
And neuer trouble Peter for the matter.

speech.speaker: Cap.
speech.line: Maſſe and well ſaid, a merrie horſon, ha,
Thou ſhalt be loggerhead; good Father, ‘tis day.
The Countie will be here with Muſicke ſtraight,
For ſo he ſaid he would, I heare him neere,
Nurſe, wife, what ho? what Nurſe I ſay?
Go waken Iuliet, go and trim her vp,
Ile go and chat with Paris: hie, make haſt,
Make haſt, the Bridegroome, he is come already:
Make haſt I ſay.

speech.speaker: Nur.
speech.line: Miſtris, what Miſtris? Iuliet? Faſt I warrant her ſhe.
Why Lambe, why Lady? fie you ſluggabed,
Why Loue I ſay? Madam, ſweet heart: why Bride?
What not a word? You take your peniworths now.
Sleepe for a weeke, for the next night I warrant
The Countie Paris hath ſet vp his reſt,
That you ſhall reſt but little, God forgiue me:
Marrie and Amen: how ſound is ſhe a ſleepe?
I muſt needs wake her: Madam, Madam, Madam,
I, let the Countie take you in your bed,
Heele fright you vp yfaith. Will it not be?
What dreſt, and in your clothes, and downe againe?
I muſt needs wake you: Lady, Lady, Lady?
Alas, alas, helpe, helpe, my Ladyes dead,
Oh weladay, that euer I was borne,
Some Aqua-vitæ ho, my Lord, my Lady?

speech.speaker: Mo.
speech.line: What noiſe is heere?

speech.speaker: Nur.
speech.line: O lamentable day.

speech.speaker: Mo.
speech.line: What is the matter?

speech.speaker: Nur.
speech.line: Looke, looke, oh heauie day.

speech.speaker: Mo.
speech.line: O me, O me, my Child, my onely life:
Reuiue, looke vp, or I will die with thee:
Helpe, helpe, call helpe.

speech.speaker: Fa.
speech.line: For ſhame bring Iuliet forth, her Lord is come.

speech.speaker: Nur.
speech.line: Shee’s dead: deceaſt, ſhee’s dead: alacke the day.

speech.speaker: M.
speech.line: Alacke the day, ſhee’s dead, ſhee’s dead, ſhee’s dead.

speech.speaker: Fa.
speech.line: Ha? Let me ſee her: out alas ſhee’s cold,
Her blood is ſetled and her ioynts are ſtiffe:
Life and theſe lips haue long bene ſeperated:
Death lies on her like an vntimely froſt
Vpon the ſweteſt flower of all the field.

speech.speaker: Nur.
speech.line: O Lamentable day!

speech.speaker: Mo.
speech.line: O wofull time.

speech.speaker: Fa.
speech.line: Death that hath tane her hence to make me waile,
Ties vp my tongue, and will not let me ſpeake.

speech.speaker: Fri.
speech.line: Come, is the Bride ready to go to Church?

speech.speaker: Fa.
speech.line: Ready to go, but neuer to returne.
O Sonne, the night before thy wedding day,
Hath death laine with thy wife: there ſhe lies,
Flower as ſhe was, deflowred by him.
Death is my Sonne in law, death is my Heire,
My Daughter he hath wedded. I will die,
And leaue him all life liuing, all is deaths.

speech.speaker: Pa.
speech.line: Haue I thought long to ſee this mornings face,
And doth it giue me ſuch a ſight as this?

speech.speaker: Mo.
speech.line: Accur’ſt, vnhappie, wretched hatefull day,
Moſt miſerable houre, that ere time ſaw
In laſting labour of his Pilgrimage.
But one, poore one, one poore and louing Child,
But one thing to reioyce and ſolace in,
And cruell death hath catcht it from my ſight.

speech.speaker: Nur.
speech.line: O wo, O wofull, wofull, wofull day,
Moſt lamentable day, moſt wofull day,
That euer, euer, I did yet behold.
O day, O day, O day, O hatefull day,
Neuer was ſeene ſo blacke a day as this:
O wofull day, O wofull day.

speech.speaker: Pa.
speech.line: Beguild, diuorced, wronged, ſpighted, ſlaine,
Moſt deteſtable death, by thee beguil’d,
By cruell, cruell thee, quite ouerthrowne:
O loue, O life; not life, but loue in death.

speech.speaker: Fat.
speech.line: Deſpis’d, diſtreſſed, hated, martir’d, kil’d,
Vncomfortable time, why cam’ſt thou now
To murther, murther our ſolemnitie?
O Child, O Child; my ſoule, and not my Child,
Dead art thou, alacke my Child is dead,
And with my Child, my ioyes are buried.

speech.speaker: Fri.
speech.line: Peace ho for ſhame, confuſions: Care liues not
In theſe confuſions, heauen and your ſelfe
Had part in this faire Maid, now heauen hath all,
And all the better is it for the Maid:
Your part in her, you could not keepe from death,
But heauen keepes his part in eternall life:
The moſt you ſought was her promotion,
For ‘twas your heauen, ſhe ſhouldſt be aduan’ſt,
And weepe ye now, ſeeing ſhe is aduan’ſt
Aboue the Cloudes, as high as Heauen it ſelfe?
O in this loue, you loue your Child ſo ill,
That you run mad, ſeeing that ſhe is well:
Shee’s not well married, that liues married long,
But ſhee’s beſt married, that dies married yong.
Drie vp your teares, and ſticke your Roſemarie
On this faire Coarſe, and as the cuſtome is,
And in her beſt array beare her to Church:
For though ſome Nature bids all vs lament,
Yet Natures teares are Reaſons merriment.

speech.speaker: Fa.
speech.line: All things that we ordained Feſtiuall,
Turne from their office to blacke Funerall:
Our inſtruments to melancholy Bells,
Our wedding cheare, to a ſad buriall Feaſt:
Our ſolemne Hymnes, to ſullen Dyrges change:
Our Bridall flowers ſerue for a buried Coarſe:
And all things change them to the contrarie.

speech.speaker: Fri.
speech.line: Sir go you in; and Madam, go with him,
And go ſir Paris, euery one prepare
To follow this faire Coarſe vnto her graue:
The heauens do lowre vpon you, for ſome ill:
Moue them no more, by croſſing their high will.

speech.speaker: Mu.
speech.line: Faith we may put vp our Pipes and be gone.

speech.speaker: Nur.
speech.line: Honeſt goodfellowes: Ah put vp, put vp,
For well you know, this is a pitifull caſe.

speech.speaker: Mu.
speech.line: I by my troth, the caſe may be amended.

speech.speaker: Pet.
speech.line: Muſitions, oh Muſitions,
Hearts eaſe, hearts eaſe,
O, and you will haue me liue, play hearts eaſe.

speech.speaker: Mu.
speech.line: Why hearts eaſe;

speech.speaker: Pet.
speech.line: O Muſitions,
Becauſe my heart it ſelfe plaies, my heart is full.

speech.speaker: Mu.
speech.line: Not a dump we, ‘tis no time to play now.

speech.speaker: Pet.
speech.line: You will not then?

speech.speaker: Mu.
speech.line: No.

speech.speaker: Pet.
speech.line: I will then giue it you ſoundly.

speech.speaker: Mu.
speech.line: What will you giue vs?

speech.speaker: Pet.
speech.line: No money on my faith, but the gleeke.
I will giue you the Minſtrell.

speech.speaker: Mu.
speech.line: Then will I giue you the Seruing creature.

speech.speaker: Peter.
speech.line: Then will I lay the ſeruing Creatures Dagger
on your pate. I will carie no Crochets, Ile Re you, Ile Fa
you, do you note me?

speech.speaker: Mu.
speech.line: And you Re vs, and Fa vs, you Note vs.

speech.speaker: 2.M.
speech.line: Pray you put vp your Dagger,
And put out your wit.
Then haue at you with my wit.

speech.speaker: Peter.
speech.line: I will drie-beate you with an yron wit,
And put vp my yron Dagger.
Anſwere me like men:
When griping griefes the heart doth wound, then Mu—
ſicke with her ſiluer ſound.
Why ſiluer ſound? why Muſicke with her ſiluer ſound?
what ſay you Simon Catling?

speech.speaker: Mu.
speech.line: Mary ſir, becauſe ſiluer hath a ſweet ſound.

speech.speaker: Pet.
speech.line: Prateſt, what ſay you Hugh Rebicke?

speech.speaker: 2.M.
speech.line: I ſay ſiluer ſound, becauſe Muſitions ſound for ſiluer

speech.speaker: Pet.
speech.line: Prateſt to, what ſay you Iames Sound-Post?

speech.speaker: 3.Mu.
speech.line: Faith I know not what to ſay.

speech.speaker: Pet.
speech.line: O I cry you mercy, you are the Singer.
I will ſay for you; it is Muſicke with her ſiluer ſound,
Becauſe Muſitions haue no gold for ſounding:
Then Muſicke with her ſiluer ſound, with ſpeedy helpe
doth lend redreſſe.

speech.speaker: Mu.
speech.line: What a peſtilent knaue is this ſame?

speech.speaker: M.2.
speech.line: Hang him Iacke, come weele in here, tarrie for
the Mourners, and ſtay dinner.

speech.speaker: Rom.
speech.line: If I may truſt the flattering truth of ſleepe,
My dreames preſage ſome ioyfull newes at hand:
My boſomes L. ſits lightly in his throne:
And all thisan day an vnaccuſtom’d ſpirit,
Lifts me aboue the ground with cheerefull thoughts.
I dreamt my Lady came and found me dead,
(Strange dreame that giues a dead man leaue to thinke,)
And breath’d ſuch life with kiſſes in my lips,
That I reuiu’d and was an Emperour.
Ah me, how ſweet is loue it ſelfe poſſeſt,
When but loues ſhadowes are ſo rich in ioy.
Newes from Verona, how now Balthazer?
Doſt thou not bring me Letters from the Frier?
How doth my Lady? Is my Father well?
How doth my Lady Iuliet? that I aske againe,
For nothing can be ill, if ſhe be well.

speech.speaker: Man.
speech.line: Then ſhe is well, and nothing can be ill.
Her body ſleepes in Capels Monument,
And her immortall part with Angels liue,
I ſaw her laid low in her kindreds Vault,
And preſently tooke Poſte to tell it you:
O pardon me for bringing theſe ill newes,
Since you did leaue it for my office Sir.

speech.speaker: Rom.
speech.line: Is it euen ſo?
Then I denie you Starres.
Thou knoweſt my lodging, get me inke and paper,
And hire Poſt-Horſes, I will hence to night.

speech.speaker: Man.
speech.line: I do beseech you ſir, haue patience:
Your lookes are pale and wild, and do import
Some miſaduenture.

speech.speaker: Rom.
speech.line: Tuſh, thou art deceiu’d,
Leaue me, and do the thing I bid thee do.
Haſt thou no Letters to me from the Frier?

speech.speaker: Man.
speech.line: No my good Lord.

speech.speaker: Rom.
speech.line: No matter: Get thee gone,
And hyre thoſe Horſes, Ile be with thee ſtraight,
Well Iuliet, I will lie with thee to night:
Lets ſee for meanes, O miſchiefe thou art ſwift,
To enter in the thoughts of deſperate men:
I do remember an Appothecarie,
And here abouts dwells, which late I noted
In tattred weeds, with ouerwhelming browes,
Culling of Simples, meager were his lookes,
Sharp miſerie had worne him to the bones:
And in his needie ſhop a Tortoyrs hung,
An Allegater ſtuft, and other ſkins
Of ill ſhap’d fiſhes, and about his ſhelues,
A beggerly account of emptie boxes,
Greene earthen pots, Bladders, and muſtie ſeedes,
Remnants of packthred, and old cakes of Roſes
Were thinly ſcattered, to make vp a ſhew.
Noting this penury, to my ſelfe I ſaid,
An if a man did need a poyſon now,
Whoſe ſale is perſent death in Mantua,
Here liues a Caitiffe wretch would ſell it him.
O this ſame thought did but fore-run my need,
And this ſame needie man muſt ſell it me.
As I remember, this ſhould be the houſe,
Being holy day, the beggers ſhop is ſhut.
What ho? Appothecarie?

speech.speaker: App.
speech.line: Who call’s ſo low’d?

speech.speaker: Rom.
speech.line: Come hither man, I ſee that thou art poore,
Hold, there is fortie Duckets, let me haue
A dram of poyſon, ſuch ſoone ſpeeding geare,
As will diſperſe it ſelfe through all the veines,
That the life-wearie-taker may fall dead,
And that the Trunke may be diſcharg’d of breath,
As violently, as haſtie powder fier’d
Doth hurry from the fatall Canons wombe.

speech.speaker: App.
speech.line: Such mortall drugs I haue, but Mantuas law
Is death to any he, that vtters them.

speech.speaker: Rom.
speech.line: Art thou ſo bare and full of wretchedneſſe,
And fear’ſt to die? Famine is in thy cheekes,
Need and opreſſion ſtarueth in thy eyes,
Contempt and beggery hangs vpon thy backe:
The world is not thy friend, nor the worlds law:
The world affords no law to make thee rich.
Then be not poore, but breake it, and take this.

speech.speaker: App.
speech.line: My pouerty, but not my will conſents.

speech.speaker: Rom.
speech.line: I pray thy pouerty, and not thy will.

speech.speaker: App.
speech.line: Put this in any liquid thing you will
And drinke it off, and if you had the ſtrength
Of twenty men, it would diſpatch you ſtraight.

speech.speaker: Rom.
speech.line: There’s thy Gold,
Worſe poyſon to mens ſoules,
Doing more murther in this loathſome world,
Then theſe poore compounds that thou maieſt not ſell.
I ſell thee poyſon, thou haſt ſold me none,
Farewell, buy food, and get thy ſelfe in fleſh.
Come Cordiall, and not poyſon, go with me
To Iuliets graue, for there muſt I vſe thee.

scene.stagedir: Enter Frier Iohn to Frier Lawrence.

speech.speaker: Iohn.
speech.line: Holy Franciſcan Frier, Brother, ho?

speech.speaker: Law.
speech.line: This ſame ſhould be the voice of Frier Iohn.
Welcome from Mantua, what ſayes Romeo?
Or if his mind be writ, giue me his Letter.

speech.speaker: Iohn.
speech.line: Going to find a bare-foote Brother out,
One of our order to aſſociate me,
Here in this Citie viſiting the ſick,
And finding him, the Searchers of the Towne
Suspeƈting that we both were in a houſe
Where the infeƈtious peſtilence did raigne,
Seal’d vp the doores, and would not let vs forth,
So that my ſpeed to Mantua there was ſtaid.

speech.speaker: Law.
speech.line: Who bare my Letter then to Romeo?

speech.speaker: Iohn.
speech.line: I could not ſend it, here it is againe,
Nor get a meſſenger to bring it thee,
So fearefull were they of infeƈtion.

speech.speaker: Law.
speech.line: Vnhappie Fortune: by my Brotherhood
The Letter was not nice; but full of charge,
Of deare import; and the negleƈting it
May do much danger: Frier Iohn go hence,
Get me an Iron Crow, and bring it ſtraight
Vnto my Cell.

speech.speaker: Iohn
speech.line: Brother Ile go and bring it thee.

speech.speaker: Law.
speech.line: Now muſt I to the Monument alone,
Within this three houres will faire Iuliet wake,
Shee will beſhrew me much that Romeo
Hath had no notice of theſe accidents:
But I will write againe to Mantua,
And keepe her at my Cell till Romeo come,
Poore liuing Coarſe, clos’d in a dead mans Tombe,

speech.speaker: Par.
speech.line: Giue me thy Torch Boy, hence and ſtand aloft,
Yet put it out, for I would not be ſeene:
Vnder yond young Trees lay thee all along,
Holding thy eare cloſe to the hollow ground,
So ſhall no foot vpon the Churchyard tread,
Being looſe, vnfirme with digging vp of Graues,
But thou ſhalt heare it: whiſtle then to me,
As ſignall that thou heareſt ſome thing approach,
Giue me thoſe flowers. Do as I bid thee, go.

speech.speaker: Page.
speech.line: I am almoſt afraid to ſtand alone
Here in the Churchyard, yet I will aduenture.

speech.speaker: Pa.
speech.line: Sweet Flower with flowers thy Bridall bed I ſtrew:
O woe, thy Canopie is duſt and ſtones,
Which with ſweet water nightly I will dewe,
Or wanting that, with teares deſtil’d by mones;
The obſequies that I for thee will keepe,
Nightly ſhall be, to ſtrew thy graue, and weepe.
The Boy giues warning, ſomething doth approach,
What curſed foot wanders this wayes to night,
To croſſe my obſequies, and true loues right?
What with a Torch? Muffle me night a while.

speech.speaker: Rom.
speech.line: Giue me that Mattocke, & the wrenching Iron,
Hold take this Letter, early in the morning
See thou deliuer it to my Lord and Father,
Giue me the light; vpon thy life I charge thee,
What ere thou hear’ſt or ſeeſt, ſtand all aloofe,
And do not interrupt me in my courſe.
Why I deſcend into this bed of death,
Is partly to behold my Ladies face:
But chiefly to take thence from her dead finger,
A precious Ring, a Ring that I muſt vſe,
In deare employment, therefore hence be gone:
But if thou iealous doſt returne to prie
In what I further ſhall intend to do,
By heauen I will teare thee ioynt by ioynt,
And ſtrew this hungry Churchyard with thy limbs:
The time, and my intents are ſauage wilde:
More fierce and more inexorable farre,
Then emptie Tygers, or the roaring Sea.

speech.speaker: Pet.
speech.line: I will be gone ſir, and not trouble you

speech.speaker: Ro.
speech.line: So ſhalt thou ſhew me friendſhip: take thou that,
Liue and be proſperous, and farewell good fellow.

speech.speaker: Pet.
speech.line: For all this ſame, Ile hide me here about,
His lookes I feare, and his intents I doubt.

speech.speaker: Rom.
speech.line: Thou deteſtable mawe, thou wombe of death,
Gorg’d with the deareſt morſell of the earth:
Thus I enforce thy rotten Iawes to open,
And in deſpight, Ile cram thee with more food.

speech.speaker: Par.
speech.line: This is that baniſht haughtie Mountague,
That murdred my Loues Cozin; with which griefe,
It is ſuppoſed the faire Creature died,
And here is come to do ſome villanous ſhame
To the dead bodies: I will apprehend him.
Stop thy vnhallowed toyle, vile Mountague:
Can vengeance be purſued further then death?
Condemned villaine, I do apprehend thee.
Obey and go with me, for thou muſt die,

speech.speaker: Rom.
speech.line: I muſt indeed, and therfore came I hither:
Good gentle youth, tempt not a deſperate man,
Flie hence and leaue me, thinke vpon thoſe gone,
Let them affright thee. I beſeech thee Youth,
Put not an other ſin vpon my head,
By vrging me to furie. O be gone,
By heauen I loue thee better then my ſelfe,
For I come hither arm’d against my ſelfe:
Stay not, be gone, liue, and hereafter ſay,
A mad mans mercy bid thee run away.

speech.speaker: Par.
speech.line: I do defie thy commiſſeration,
And apprehend thee for a Fellon here.

speech.speaker: Ro.
speech.line: Wilt thou prouoke me? Then haue at thee Boy.

speech.speaker: Pet.
speech.line: O Lord they fight, I will go call the Watch.

speech.speaker: Pa.
speech.line: O I am ſlaine, if thou be mercifull,
Open the Tombe, lay me with Iuliet.

speech.speaker: Rom.
speech.line: In faith I will, let me peruſe this face:
Mercutius kinſman, Noble Countie Paris,
What ſaid my man, when my betoſſed ſoule
Did not attend him as we rode? I thinke
He told me Paris ſhould haue married Iuliet.
Said he not ſo? Or did I dreame it ſo?
Or am I mad, hearing him talke of Iuliet,
To thinke it was ſo? O giue me thy hand,
One, writ with me in ſowre misfortunes booke.
Ile burie thee in a triumphant graue.
A Graue; O no, a Lanthorne; ſlaughtred Youth:
For here lies Iuliet, and her beautie makes
This Vault a feaſting preſence full of light.
Death lie thou there, by a dead man inter’d,
How oft when men are at the point of death,
Haue they beene merrie? Which their Keepers call
A lightning before death? Oh how may I
Call this a lightning? O my Loue, my Wife,
Death that hath ſuckt the honey of thy breath,
Hath had no power yet vpon thy Beautie:
Thou are not conquer’d: Beauties enſigne yet
Is Crymſon in thy lips, and in thy cheekes,
And Deaths pale flag is not aduanced there.
Tybalt, ly’ſt thou there in thy bloudy ſheet?
O what more fauour can I do to thee,
Then with that hand that cut thy youth in twaine,
To ſunder his that was thy enemie?
Forgiue me Cozen. Ah deare Iuliet:
Why art thou yet ſo faire? I will beleeue,
Shall I beleeue, that vnſubſtantiall death is amorous?
And that the leane abhorred Monſter keepes
Thee here in darke to be his Paramour?
For feare of that, I ſtill will ſtay with thee,
And neuer from this Pallace of dym night
Depart againe: come lie thou in my armes,
Heere’s to thy health, where ere thou tumbleſt in.
O true Appothecarie!
Thy drugs are quicke. Thus with a kiſſe I die.
Depart againe; here, here will I remaine,
With Wormes that are thy Chambermaides: O here
Will I ſet vp my euerlaſting reſt:
And ſhake the yoke of inauſpicious ſtarres
From this world-wearied fleſh: Eyes looke your laſt:
Armes take your laſt embrace: And lips, O you
The doores of breath, ſeale with a righteous kiſſe
A dateleſſe bargaine to ingroſſing death:
Come bitter conduƈt, come vnſauoury guide,
Thou deſperate Pilot, now at once run on
The daſhing Rocks, thy Sea-ſicke wearie Barke:
Heere's to my Loue. O true Appothecary:
Thy drugs are quicke. Thus with a kiſſe I die.

scene.stagedir: Enter Frier with a Lanthorne, Crow, and Spade.

speech.speaker: Fri.
speech.line: St. Francis be my ſpeed, how oft to night
Haue my old feet ſtumbled at graues? Who’s there?

speech.speaker: Man.
speech.line: Here’s one, a Friend, & one that knowes you well.

speech.speaker: Fri.
speech.line: Bliſſe be vpon you. Tell me good my Friend
What Torch is yond that vainely lends his light
To grubs, and eyeleſſe Sculles? As I diſcerne,
It burneth in the Capels Monument.

speech.speaker: Man.
speech.line: It doth ſo holy ſir,
And there’s my Maſter, one that you loue.

speech.speaker: Fri.
speech.line: Who is it?

speech.speaker: Man.
speech.line: Romeo.

speech.speaker: Fri.
speech.line: How long hath he bin there?

speech.speaker: Man.
speech.line: Full halfe an houre.

speech.speaker: Fri.
speech.line: Go with me to the Vault.

speech.speaker: Man.
speech.line: I dare not Sir.
My Maſter knowes not but I am gone hence,
And fearefully did menace me with death,
If I did ſtay to looke on his entents.

speech.speaker: Fri.
speech.line: Stay, then Ile go alone, feares comes vpon me.
O much I feare ſome ill vnluckie thing.

speech.speaker: Man.
speech.line: As I did ſleepe vnder this young tree here,
I dreamt my maiſter and another fought,
And that my Maiſter ſlew him.

speech.speaker: Fri.
speech.line: Romeo.
Alacke, alacke, what blood is this which ſtaines
The ſtony entrance of this Sepulcher?
What meane theſe Maſterleſſe, and goarie Swords
To lie diſcolour’d by this place of peace?
Romeo, oh pale: who elſe? what Paris too?
And ſteept in blood? Ah what an vnkind houre
Is guiltie of this lamentable chance?
The Lady ſtirs.

speech.speaker: Iul.
speech.line: O comfortable Frier, where’s my Lord?
I do remember well where I ſhould be:
And there I am, where is my Romeo?

speech.speaker: Fri.
speech.line: I heare ſome noyſe Lady, come from that neſt
Of death, contagion, and vnnaturall ſleepe,
A greater power then we can contradiƈt
Hath thwarted our entents, come, come away,
Thy husband in thy boſome there lies dead:
And Paris too: come Ile diſpoſe of thee,
Among a Siſterhood of holy Nunnes:
Stay not to queſtion, for the watch is comming.
Come, go good Iuliet, I dare no longer ſtay.

speech.speaker: Iul.
speech.line: Go get thee hence, for I will not away,
What’s here? A cup clos’d in my true loues hand?
Poyſon I ſee hath bin his timeleſſe end
O churle, drinke all? and left no friendly drop,
To helpe me after, I will kiſſe thy lips,
Happlie ſome poyſon yet doth hang on them,
To make me die with a reſtoratiue.
Thy lips are warme.

speech.speaker: Watch.
speech.line: Lead Boy, which way?

speech.speaker: Iul.
speech.line: Yea noiſe?
Then ile be briefe. O happy Dagger.
‘Tis in thy ſheath, there ruſt and let me die.

speech.speaker: Boy.
speech.line: This is the place,
There where the Torch doth burne

speech.speaker: Watch.
speech.line: The ground is bloody,
Search about the Churchyard.
Go ſome of you, who ere you find attach.
Pittifull ſight, here lies the Countie ſlaine,
And Iuliet bleeding, warme and newly dead
Who here hath laine theſe two dayes buried.
Go tell the Prince, runne to the Capulets,
Raiſe vp the Mountagues, ſome others ſearch,
We ſee the ground whereon theſe woes do lye,
But the true ground of all theſe piteous woes,
We cannot without circumſtance deſcry.

speech.speaker: Watch.
speech.line: Here’s Romeo’s man,
We found him in the Churchyard.

speech.speaker: Con.
speech.line: Hold him in ſafety, till the Prince come hither.

speech.speaker: 3.Wat.
speech.line: Here is a Frier that trembles, ſighes, and weepes
We tooke this Mattocke and this Spade from him,
As he was comming from this Church-yard ſide.

speech.speaker: Con.
speech.line: A great ſuſpition, ſtay the Frier too.

speech.speaker: Prin.
speech.line: What miſaduenture is ſo earely vp,
That calls our perſon from our mornings reſt?

speech.speaker: Cap.
speech.line: What ſhould it be that they ſo ſhrike abroad?

speech.speaker: Wife.
speech.line: O the people in the ſtreete crie Romeo.
Some Iuliet, and ſome Paris, and all runne
With open outcry toward our Monument.

speech.speaker: Pri.
speech.line: What feare is this which ſtartles in your eares?

speech.speaker: Wat.
speech.line: Soueraigne, here lies the Countie Paris ſlaine,
And Romeo dead, and Iuliet dead before,
Warme and new kil’d.

speech.speaker: Prin.
speech.line: Search,
Seeke, and know how, this foule murder comes.

speech.speaker: Wat.
speech.line: Here is a Frier, and Slaughter’d Romeos man,
With Inſtruments vpon them fit to open
Theſe dead mens Tombes.

speech.speaker: Cap.
speech.line: O heauen!
O wife looke how our Daughter bleedes!
This Dagger hath miſtaine, for loe his houſe
Is empty on the backe of Mountague,
And is miſheathed in my Daughters boſome.

speech.speaker: Wife.
speech.line: O me, this ſight of death, is as a Bell
That warnes my old age to a Sepulcher.

speech.speaker: Pri.
speech.line: Come Mountague, for thou art early vp
To ſee thy Sonne and Heire, now early downe.

speech.speaker: Moun.
speech.line: Alas my liege, my wife is dead to night,
Griefe of my Sonnes exile hath ſtopt her breath:
What further woe conſpires againſt my age?

speech.speaker: Prin.
speech.line: Looke: and thou ſhalt ſee.

speech.speaker: Moun.
speech.line: O thou vntaught, what manners in is this,
To preſſe before thy Father to a graue?

speech.speaker: Prin.
speech.line: Seale vp the mouth of outrage for a while,
Till we can cleare theſe ambiguities,
And know their ſpring, their head, their true deſcent,
And then will I be generall of your woes,
And lead you euen to death? meane time forbeare,
And let miſchance be ſlaue to patience,
Bring forth the parties of ſuſpition.

speech.speaker: Fri.
speech.line: I am the greateſt, able to doe leaſt,
Yet moſt ſuſpeƈted as the time and place
Doth make againſt me of this direfull murther:
And heere I ſtand both to impeach and purge
My ſelfe condemned, and my ſelfe excuſ’d.

speech.speaker: Prin.
speech.line: Then ſay at once, what thou doſt know in this?

speech.speaker: Fri.
speech.line: I will be briefe, for my ſhort date of breath
Is not ſo long as is a tedious tale.
Romeo there dead, was husband to that Iuliet,
And ſhe there dead, that’s Romeos faithfull wife:
I married them; and their ſtolne marriage day
Was Tybalts Doomeſday: whoſe vntimely death
Baniſh’d the new-made Bridegroome from this Citie:
For whom (and not for Tybalt) Iuliet pinde.
You, to remoue that ſiege of Greefe from her,
Betroth’d, and would haue married her perforce
To Countie Paris. Then comes ſhe to me,
And (with wilde lookes) bid me deuiſe ſome meanes
To rid her from this ſecond Marriage,
Or in my Cell there would ſhe kill her ſelfe.
Then gaue I her (so Tutor’d by my Art)
A ſleeping Potion, which ſo tooke effeƈt
As I intended, for it wrought on her
The forme of death. Meane time, I writ to Romeo,
That he ſhould hither come, as this dyre night,
To helpe to take her from her borrowed graue,
Being the time the Potions force ſhould ceaſe.
But he which bore my Letter, Frier Iohn,
Was ſtay’d by accident; and yeſternight
Return’d my Letter backe. Then all alone,
At the prefixed houre of her waking,
Came I to take her from her Kindreds vault,
Meaning to keepe her cloſely at my Cell,
Till I conueniently could ſend to Romeo.
But when I came (some Minute ere the time
Of her awaking) heere vntimely lay
The Noble Paris, and true Romeo dead.
Shee wakes, and I intreated her come foorth,
And beare this worke of Heauen, with patience:
But then, a noyſe did ſcarre me from the Tombe,
And ſhe (too deſperate) would not go with me,
But (as it ſeemes) did violence on her ſelfe.
All this I know, and to the Marriage her Nurſe is priuy:
And if ought in this miſcarried by my fault,
Let my old life be ſacrific’d, ſome houre before the time,
Vnto the rigour of ſeuereſt Law.

speech.speaker: Prin.
speech.line: We ſtill haue knowne thee for a Holy man.
Where’s Romeo’s man? What can he ſay to this?

speech.speaker: Boy.
speech.line: I brought my Maſter newes of Iuliets death,
And then in poſte he came from Mantua
To this ſame place, to this ſame Monument.
This Letter he early bid me giue his Father,
And threatned me with death, going in the Vault,
If I departed not, and left him there.

speech.speaker: Prin.
speech.line: Giue me the Letter, I will look on it.
Where is the Counties Page that rais’d the Watch?
Sirra, what made your Maſter in this place?

speech.speaker: Page.
speech.line: He came with flowres to ſtrew his Ladies graue,
And bid me ſtand aloofe, and ſo I did:
Anon comes one with light to ope the Tombe,
And by and by my Maiſter drew on him,
And then I ran away to call the Watch.

speech.speaker: Prin.
speech.line: This Letter doth make good the Friers words,
Their courſe of Loue, the tydings of her death:
And heere he writes, that he did buy a poyſon
Of a poore Pothecarie, and therewithall
Came to this Vault to dye, and lye with Iuliet.
Where be theſe Enemies? Capulet, Mountague,
See what a ſcourge is laide vpon your hate,
That Heauen finds meanes to kill your ioyes with Loue;
And I, for winking at your diſcords too,
Haue loſt a brace of Kinſmen: All are puniſh’d.

speech.speaker: Cap.
speech.line: O Brother Mountague, giue me thy hand,
This is my Daughters ioynture, for no more
Can I demand.

speech.speaker: Moun.
speech.line: But I can giue thee more:
For I will raiſe her Statue in pure Gold,
That whiles Verona by that name is knowne,
There ſhall no figure at that Rate be ſet,
As that of True and Faithfull Iuliet.

speech.speaker: Cap.
speech.line: As rich ſhall Romeo by his Lady ly,
Poore ſacrifices of our enmity.

speech.speaker: Prin.
speech.line: A glooming peace this morning with it brings,
The Sunne for ſorrow will not ſhew his head;
Go hence, to haue more talke of theſe ſad things,
Some ſhall be pardon’d, and ſome puniſhed.
For neuer was a Storie of more Wo,
Then this of Iuliet, and her Romeo.
